This issue has been received by the City of Sandy Springs. Your service request ID is #18-039567.

I feel for you & your curb situation. I wish I had a curb. Moreso, I wish that there was a sewer on my corner, Long Island Dr. - no sewer uphill from me, & none on Johnson Ferry for many blocks. When it rains, there are 2 rivers flowing at my corner. Other corner rd. is Long Island Pl. sewer is too far to help. The result, a constant pond and soot deposit that overflows onto my turf & bringing with it a constant weed infestation. All of the sitting water over the decades ruin the asphalt re-pavings. 3 re-pavings during my ownership, & it's time for another one. It'd be cheaper to grant us a corner sewer. Will they? I won't live long enough to see it. Maybe you'll have better luck. I expect zero from Sandy Springs except a yearly bill. Nice website. Makes it look like you might even care.

The pedestrian time is long because the total cycle length is long, not the other way around.  The cycle length is long that early in the morning to get ahead of the heavy volumes that are about to start.

I do agree that the cycle time is longer than it used to be, before the pedestrian time was added, but I submit that it is not necessary for either the Ashford-Dunwoody traffic or pedestrians.

I've been driving this route for almost 4 years and I can count on one hand the number of pedestrians that have crossed this intersection between 6:00 and 6:15 AM when I go through it.  And, they have all crossed Ashford-Dunwoody, not Hammond.  So, there are, for all intents and purposes, no pedestrians to initiate the Hammond crosswalk signal.  

Between 6:00 and 6:15 AM there is no heavy traffic on Ashford-Dunwoody, unless another stoplight's timing is also messed up.  Getting ahead of traffic just slows the early traffic down unnecessarily.  Can you refine the time when the extended cycle must begin?

One other thought for the northbound Ashford-Dunwoody traffic turning onto Hammond; there is a busy intersection near my home with a high volume of traffic making a left turn.  To alleviate this, there is a left turn only at the beginning of the cycle and end of the cycle. Hope this is helpful.

Thanks

This should be an adopted zero tolerance initiative in East Point!

I already made a complaint about this more than 6 months ago. It's not storm damage. The new owners of the property decided to 'demolish' it using 3 guys in a pickup truck. I asked the city of EP in the complaint 6 months ago if a permit to demolish had been filed - no response on that point. I asked exactly how long the owners have to complete work once it was started because at that time the house had been in that state for at least 6 months - the permit office's response was that there was no time requirement, which seems crazy. My primary concern is public safety, in that the site is a disaster waiting to happen regarding people, pets and kids. It's not secured in any way and the whole floor with gaping holes is suspended above a debris (glass, bricks, boards with nails, etc) filled basement. 

It's an embarrassment to the city and represents financial exposure because the complaints are on record - the city has known about it for over a year now. If you dared to make a backyard deck more than 14 inches of the ground without a code-compliant handrail, the city of East Point would cite you.. The owners of this property must have some city connection(s) - I can think of no reason for the city of have let this situation go on so long. East Point zoning trucks travel down Newnan street multiple times a day - *Where are the all going* if they can't see this?
Something needs to done. It’s incredibly ugly for our neighborhood and east point!
City of East Point gets zero results yet again.

It's a version of the 80/20 rule. 80% of the properties which are the real horrors of Colonial Hill -- the properties that make the whole area look bad -- are investor or 'future' developer-owned properties. These owners intentionally *do not want to be found* -- they are interested in playing the longest game possible, playing rope-a-dope with the city, refusing to invest in even the most minimal of maintenance, and we are all suffering in the process.

The City of East Point needs to pull a few bucks off the top of the budget for all the new municipal building that's going on downtown and instead hire a some legal talent to go after the owners of these trash-piles. Fine them, or seize and sell the properties to responsible parties -- the short, the mayor and the other civil servants that we pay need to *do their job* -- other cities have read the riot act to owners like this, and in the process transformed neighborhoods for their constituents  -- Where is our man on the street Thomas Callahan in all this? It's disgusting. It truly is.
070318- Will investigate. Acknowledged.

Still no real results from The City of East Point Code Enforcement. Decades of decay and they send another letter then simply give up. No wonder absentee owners get away with this for years. Yes years! Let's change the system. We are citizens and can vote.

comment_text: Decatur Public Works - David Junger assigned this issue to Decatur Public Works - David Junger
Decatur Public Works - M Hirose assigned this issue to Decatur Public Works-S Smith
Absolutely agree! Not only are they now unsightly after a very short time since installation, the current crosswalks do not offer adequate safety for walkers.

I liked the crosswalks and their vibrant, non-traditional colors and symbols, which also comply with environmental design research that indicates that making a place and signage  ‘custom looking and people-made’ rather than just ‘same old plain technical looking’ standard causes drivers to slow down. 

If it needs touching up, that’s to be expected. Let the City staff consider their options.

The problem is cars going too fast over the crosswalks and scraping their undersides, even after they’ve been warned by signage. Maybe fines, speed enforcement, cameras to catch speeders, or a ‘shaming squad’ could help. Or make all such crossing a full stop for all vehicles.  The crosswalk itself is not misbehaving;)

Crosswalks are intended primarily for safety of pedestrians. Drivers respond to standard designs that tell them standard safety messages, such as STOP for pedestrians. That is why we have a standard shape for stop signs, as opposed to freeform information signs. 

We want our neighborhood crosswalk to warn drivers to stop for pedestrians. As long as it is properly maintained, we do not need to have drawings of footprints and dog paws on the crosswalk. We need crosswalks that send a strong message to drivers: this is a crosswalk for walkers.
Will take up with City Engineer

Please leave this open until crosswalks are repaired. The crosswalks in their current state are not easily visible. If the colorful patterned crosswalk designs are repairable please do so. If they are not repairable please replace with a traditional paint based crosswalk pattern.
Acknowledged
Decatur Public Works - M Hirose assigned this issue to Decatur Public Works-S Smith
Will take up with City Engineer
City Engineer issue

Please leave this open until crosswalks are repaired. The crosswalks in their current state are not easily visible. If the colorful patterned crosswalk designs are repairable please do so. If they are not repairable please replace with a traditional paint based crosswalk pattern.

Robert -

Thank you for your concern.  Prior to installation, the City carefully considered the options to provide safe and interesting crosswalks in our downtown area.  The selected material is designed to retain its color as it wears down over time.  For this reason,  the City does not have immediate plans to replace the current crosswalks. 

I understand that not all resident would choose this type of crosswalk.  However, since installation, we have not received many complaints about these crosswalks.  Some people prefer the new crosswalks and many seem to like them.   I would be happy to talk with you about this over a phone call especially if there are 2-3 specific places where the material has worn away.  You can reach me directly at 678.553.6570.    John Maximuk, Director, DEC office.
I agree. This is a SAFETY issue. It is not about aesthetics and art. At least please add more effective signage for drivers.

The lack of calls does not mean there is a lack of concern. I live downtown and OFTEN hear complaints about the crosswalks. We need safety as we walk across the street. The cars are speeding through downtown, and many distracted and in-a-hurry drivers do not see pedestrians.
I often have to flag cars down by frantically waving my arms before crossing at one of the new crosswalks. This is not an issue that is solved with artistic solutions. We need safety in crossing. Drivers do not heed the art on the street. In addition, funding was used to apply these crosswalks, and now they are deteriorating beneath the traffic. Shouldn’t we get our money back from the source?
Acknowledged

Stan, Thank you for your post.
The primary contractor was notified on 6/13/18 of the dirt in the street and sidewalk.
Also, the contractor is preparing to install the new driveway.
Thank you again for your post.

The new driveway is not installed, and a 6-ft pile of dirt remains.  As you can see, it is now washing back into the street, onto the sidewalk, and down the sewer.  This project has been reported multiple times in the past. I don't understand why the city cannot ensure compliance?
Thank you, JLLH. Really don't understand why this builder is able to continue without penalties.

Thank you for your post.
This site was placed under violation and being enforced per the City ordinance.
If you have further questions, feel free to contact me at 678.614.1405.
Engineering Inspector Andrea Hedgebeth.
Morning of 06-29-18: Builder has not fully cleaned mud from street. Storm drain not protected. Is builder allowed to continue work while under violation? Workers appeared to be at site.

Stan,
This site is not under a stop work order. The contractors are allowed to work under the Notice of Violation.
I reinspected the site and the contractor has installed some erosion control measures and cleaned the sidewalk. It is still under violation and the contractor is moving forward to correcting his site.
Thank you again for your post.
Thanks for the update, Andrea.

07-01-18: I realize that five business days may not have passed (unless June 25 is included), but the builder has still not replaced protection for the storm water drain nor removed the mud in the street/gutter from previous run-off along the left side of the lot (as you face it). 

BTW, allowing five business days for correction of a run-off problem involving mud into the storm drains during a time of year with regular afternoon thunderstorms seems overly generous. I suggest the city revisit that time period. Additionally, builders typically work Saturdays, so that day should be considered a "business day" for enforcement purposes.

comment_text: Dying tree.
Thanks for forwarding this over! I just called the Parks and Recreation department to handle this issue.
Strange. This is a streetside tree, and not near the park. This is in the business district of Candler Park.
Here's a Google Maps screenshot. It's the second tree from the intersection of McLendon Avenue NE and Clifton Rd NE.  It's marked with a spray painted orange rectangle. Exposed trunk---see photo.
The Department of Parks and Recreation also handles trees that are in the city's right-of-way.
Is there a service request number for this?
When it is reported directly to the Department of Parks and Recreation there is not a service request number provided. You may call the department for updates at 404-546-6813.
I'm not sure if I missed something. This tree isn't in a park. Shall I still call Parks?
The Department of Parks and Recreation handles trees that are in the city's right-of-way during business hours (8:00am-5:00pm) and after hour requests are handled by 911.
Thanks, that's helpful to know. I called and left a message but it was not returned.
You're welcome and you may try calling them again today or emailing them at parkscustomerservice@atlantaga.gov.

Evidently, I can copy the hyperlink address and send that in an email. The recipient can open it, even if they don't have an account, and can read. the. entire. thing. I'll let you know. Posting here helps me keep track of the case file, not necessarily asking you to do anymore. Thanks.

Received an email from Parks today: "A routine service request for a tree inspection was initiated for an Office of Parks Arborist to inspect the tree located at 400 Clifton Rd NE on 06/08/2018. The service request number is SR# ARB1232 and should be used as a reference to obtain the status of this inspection. This is believed to be the same tree referenced as 402 Clifton Rd NE."
Timeframe is 45 business days from date of request. So that places the target resolution date at August 6, 2018. On my calendar!

I see the issue is listed as completed however, has the work actually been completed or is it planned for this week?  If so, maybe they are in need of even more cutting back , as  I drove by there on Sunday and still had to come into the cross walk before I could see around the very large bushes.  The concern is not only the drivers not being able to see around the very large bushes, but the  cross walk being blocked by cars.  The people walking, the children walking to BrookRun, the families with strollers are not able to cross in the cross walk, I see them most of the time walking behind the cars in order to cross the street.  Can the tall bushes be trimmed back even further?   Looking forward to hearing back and I will reopen the issue.  Thanks for your help in keeping Dunwoody Safe.

comment_text:
Hallie is correct.  The RR boxcars are behind the small apartment building at 110 Pearl St.  SE. 30316. The corner of Field & Pearl.

The dumping has taken place every couple of months..  

This is the second 311 report that I know of.    I contacted Valencia Hudson, liaison to Natalyn Archibong, early Spring and bulk pickup arrived soon thereafter.

There’s a tale to tell on this mess.  The alleged owner of the boxcars, and one supposes, the apartment building has:

—Listed the property For Sale at $81,000 - signs hung on the chain link fencing in 2014

--Held curb sales at this location periodically for the past 2-3 years.  The items appear to have been stored in the boxcars.  Old junk with a few, very few, pieces of vintage furniture, a foot pedal sewing machine (White or Singer), lamps, clothing, toys, etc

On MLK Day, 2018, the area was cleaned by a volunteer from the neighborhood.   Some of the items were from a car broken into the previous Friday evening, and were returned to the rightful owner.  

Fresh flowers have found their way into a few of the piles.

This trash pile does not appear to be from the boxcars.   Perhaps junk from a recently vacated apartment in the 110 building?  Such as the apartment-sized refrigerator, door intact, near the Herbies Curbies at Frield & Pearl
Since I was able to initiate a code violation for the property, we will inspect the property and deem the owner responsible for the compliance if it is not.
Thank you.
You're welcome
Closed
110 Pearl St.  A new collection:  Christmas decorations.
Hey Liz! Are you advising there is a newly placed pile in the right of way? If so, how long have you noticed it there?

6/11/2018
               Yes, I have photo on this iPad, will send.

Two while males left this over the weekend, 6/9 & 6/10.

I have made another request to collect the trash and debris with service request #1121867430 and if you happen to catch the dumping while in progress, please contact 911 so an officer can be dispatched.
Solution Topic: Right of Way Maintenance (ROW) Litter Removal

comment_text: Is this the new normal? Do we have to escalate a normal city service every week? I'm even ok with the schedule changing to once a month or whatever, but that's a communication issue. Some of our narrower streets can ill afford yard waste bags and piles taking up parking or sidewalk space. That's why this little issue is really a big deal, it's not just complaining.

I totally agree. I've been calling 311 almost every week for yard waste pickup since moving in ~4 months ago. It's to the point where I have started logging all the times I've had to call & I'm considering putting it in a letter to the city.

We apologize for the delay and any inconvenience it has caused your neighborhoods. Due to limited equipment availability, yard trimming collections are behind schedule. The Department of Public Works crews are working diligently to collect missed pick-ups and resume to regular scheduling as soon as they can. Please continue to reach out to us about missed collections so that we can get those requests over to the department for resolution.

Staff appreciates your concerns about street trees and the obstructions that many of them cause.  The City has a robust ongoing work program to service and remove public right of way trees.   We cannot get to all of them immediately, however please know that we work on this.  This increased rainfall this spring - 3" more than average - seems to add to the growth.

You know the owner is deceased.  Property should not have any old age tax exemptions.

comment_text:
1. Communication: Can you send a notice to Councilmember Amir Farokhi so he can notify NPU-N constituents of any infrastructure projects in their neighborhood? Otherwise, all neighborhoods in the city have neighborhood organizations, in our case, the Candler Park Neighborhood Organization at board@candlerpark.org. #amirfarokhi

2. The final paving contractor was different than the initial underlayment contractor who did the shoddy job pictured above and who sparked a whole NextDoor conversation about burned bushes and trees. The second contractor didn't do a bad job, there is minor streaking issues though. https://nextdoor.com/news_feed/?post=81131339

3. Who requested Page be paved? Page has been paved so many times over the years that the granite headers are in many places only an inch or two above the over-paved street. 

4. Meanwhile, one street over, Terrace, is down to the concrete and is a major thoroughfare to access the PATH for many bikers commuting to work. But it is missing granite headers along half the street. And needs a speed bump (traffic study) before the sidewalk egress from the Candler Park playground since that sidewalk is downhill from a sloped curve where many drivers are speeding due to momentum and gravity. Can we start service requests for Terrace Avenue including traffic study for the speed bump. Google Maps jpg will be downloaded later for exact locations. 

Again, please could the neighborhoods have more communication regarding a major road paving?  #amirfarokhi #candlerparkneighborhoodorganization 

Thanks.
Google Map identifying location at base of downslope at L-shaped curve at Marlbrook and Terrace Avenue leading to Candler Park Playground (in the background).

We will inform Councilmember Farohki and the Department of Public Works of your concern and ask that someone follow-up with you on numbers 2 and 3. Additionally, service request #1119814569 has been made for the traffic study. Thanks and enjoy the rest of your day!
Solution Topic: Traffic Study

It happens regularly as I travel that intersection daily.

Hi! You can ask for updates on this message thread. The service request number is just for your reference and ours when we ask the department for updates. A point repair is not something that can be issued in our system by us as it can only be put in by the Department of Public Works. Our initial request is for a pothole and it is then issued as a point repair once DPW goes out to inspect. We have reached out to them again regarding the turnaround time.

Yes, that message was put out by the Department of Public Works. The yard trimmings have been delayed in several areas and they will be working through this weekend to catch up.

I just spoke to Solid Waste Manager, Sherra. I like her. There was a partial pickup. 8 tons of yard waste in Candler Park yesterday. They did miss a few on my street, but they picked up mine! 

They will pick up the remainder (Oakdale, Hooper, Candler Park Drive, etc. ) tomorrow or Saturday. I gave Sherra a heads up that this weekend is Inman Park Festival and many park in Candler Park and cross Moreland to get to the festival so waiting til Saturday is not ideal. 

She said she would rearrange things but that she'd take care of us, and that I can always call her. Yay!

The City of Dunwoody has received this issue, as service request #5588. Currently, we are working on this, please check back for status updates.

This intersection has more problems than just this. I have lived in Dunwoody for over 31 years and take Old Springhouse Lane to C D Rd in the morning to get to I-285. The increase in traffic volume over this time has been incredible as you can imagine. I'm sure the drivers on Dunwoody Park coming from the other direction are unhappy as well. It doesn't look like there is room for more lanes on C D Rd so options are limited. 
One particular problem is that the two lanes on Old Springhouse don't distribute the traffic efficiently. The left lane is for left turn only, while the right lane is for right turn and straight through. Probably 90% of all traffic on Old Springhouse will turn right to get to I 285 or continue on C D Rd. If one car tries to go straight and therefore sits through a red light, all behind it have to wait. 10% of traffic either go straight or turn left. Why does left turning traffic have its own lane? The right lane should be right turn only and the left lane should be shared between left turn and straight. Of course at 8 AM, the intersection is simply overwhelmed with traffic and it is a challenge to go in any direction. Perhaps coordinating lights here and at Georgetown shopping center and at Cotillion Dr would help some.
Another issue here is the light at the end of the access ramp onto I 285 westbound. That is absolutely the most useless thing anywhere. I can't tell you how many times the ramp is backed up onto C D Rd in both directions when that light is working. When it is turned off, the ramp clears within 2 minutes. That thing just adds injury to insult. A total waste of money.
Dunwoody has my sympathy in trying to "fix" this traffic issue. Like so many places in Atlanta, the traffic volume has overwhelmed the infrastructure. Hope there is a "fix" in the works.

311, what is the estimated timeframe / fix date for this outstanding issue? Is the 311 Service request number the same as the Issue ID 4313991 listed above? Our neighborhood Sidewalk Committee would like to keep tabs on this. Thanks! #AmirFarokhi

There is a similar issue at 425 Page Avenue NE, Atlanta GA 30307. Is there any way to coordinate the two similar issues. Also, Page Avenue is supposed to be repaved today. Will they have to tear it up (post-paving) when they fix this clogged catch basin. What name is Department of Public Works using for this issue: catch basin or storm drain? The Neighborhood Organization would like to keep tabs on this. Thanks. #Amir Farokhi

Hello! Service request # 1118166392 has been issued for a storm drain cleaning at McLendon Ave and Shepard Pl however, I am hoping you can clarify a few things as we are receiving different reports about this location. Is there a storm drain at this location already? We received a request on Facebook to have a storm drain unclogged. After reviewing Google Maps it doesn't appear there is one at this intersection so if you can clarify that would be great! Also, the SeeClickFix ID number and service request # we provide are different. Your SeeClickFix ID number helps us locate your request on this website but our service request # helps us locate the request in our system. In regards to Page Ave, these 2 issues have to be kept separate since they are 2 different locations. Nothing should have to be torn down however, if it is, restoration will take place. Catch basin and storm drain are both terms we use for issues like this so whichever one you prefer works for us!

Thank you for the further clarification. I have updated the notes on service request # 1118166392 to request a storm drain be installed and this process can take up to 45 days, possibly longer with our systems not fully restored. Since this work can be scheduled, there should be a heads up is traffic will be affected.
Solution Topic: Customer Reports Street Flooding Or Possible Clogged Basin

comment_text: I apologize for inconvenience, I was just informed by Public Works that requests for new storm drains have to go through Site Development. Please reach out to them directly and submit your request by calling them at 404 330-6249 or emailing them at zoningverification@atlantaga.gov.

The service request is still open for that issue with a target resolution date of 6/13/18. Not saying it will take that long, however, that is when the request should be completed. If there are any crews performing work that may affect the water quality or anything of that nature, you all will be informed and updated accordingly.

I'll let the neighborhood know at the next Candler Park Neighborhood Organization meeting and elsewhere. Thanks for all the insight on SeeClickFix. There are things about it I like better than 311Facebook, like the Google Map. Looks like we have to go in and place notes where issues are closed if the original claimant doesn't do it. Wondering if there are any issues on your end.
We have not had any issues on our end and we encourage our customers to submit service requests through any platform they choose and find the easiest.

Per the instructions from 311 above, I contacted Site Development (Elizabeth) at 404-330-6249, who pointed me to Dept of Watershed Management Engineering (Nolton), who pointed me to the MOST (Municipal Options Sales Tax - Storm Drains point person) at 404-546-3611 at wdouty@atlantaga.gov who asked me to send him an email with the Service Request #1118166392 for 1583 McLendon Avenue NE, Atlanta GA 30307,  to verify that 1) a service request has really been initiated. 2)that this years-long issues has been escalated. #AmirFarokhi #JayTribby #candlerparkneighborhoodorganization
I see that request is open and assigned now and will be fulfilled. Being that you have a direct email contact within that department, you can contact them directly for updates or reach out to us.

It took me the better part of my workday, but I tracked down the Project Manager in the correct department (Office of Engineering Services, Strategic Asset Management Division) and the right team team (SWIT or Stormwater Investigation Team) and found out two things: 1) Google Maps dating to 2011 shows "historic ponding" at this site, 2) this Stormwater Department had never received any of the emails by neighbors on this street over the years. I did not realize this was a high-profile case but I am watching closely now.

Jus wanted to add a photo from this morning after the rains.  Typically it takes 2-4 days for this to completely dry as there is no storm drain installed here where there clearly should have been. It’s especially an issue due to the busy nature of McLendon and the danger of trying to navigate around the water.
https://s3.amazonaws.com/ugc.seeclickfix.com/transient_files/153733/d0a6a3914a8d2733c661b60c5b842e490937006b/image.png

I was informed that there is MOST (Municipal Options Sales Tax) money which is targeted towards fixing Atlanta's aging water and sewer infrastructure: things like storm drains and sewer pipes. There is funding for this, it's a matter of project managing it. https://www.atlantaga.gov/government/mayor-s-office/projects-and-initiatives/municipal-option-sales-tax-most

SWIT team member wrote that he would respond to neighbors regarding status (other departments involved, funding, etc.)of this case on 4/26/18. That
 is tomorrow.

I would continue to reach out to the SWIT Team since they advised they will be providing you with updates accordingly. They would have more up to date information about this request as we can only see what they put after they update it.

SWIT TEAM wrote today, in part, "Installing a new catch basin in the roadway would be very expensive and there are numerous other issues that can be addressed that have more serious public safety concerns at this time." 

In other words, let's kick this can down the road. It's been several years already. There is a preschool in the adjacent building and preschoolers have to walk out into the middle of a major street thoroughfare (McLendon Avenue) to go around this puddle. 

I just want to know where this issue is in the queue and if there is a target resolution date. I will continue to reach out to Engineering, as other neighbors have done over the years, and at least I have a transparent open record here that can't be deleted. 

#amirfarokhi #jaytribby #candlerparkneighborhoodorganization #candlerparksidewalkcommittee

The target resolution date for Service Request 1118166392 is 06/13/2018 at the latest. I would advise you to keep in contact with the Engineering office and also please inform us of any new developments with this crosswalk.
Solution Topic: Customer Reports Street Flooding Or Possible Clogged Basin

comment_text:
Here's the full response from today, 4/26/18. Wasn't sure, so I redacted names. But  this is a record.


Yes, and I actually have you on my calendar to respond to you today with an update.

We have investigated this issue to see what other contribution factors may be involved in this matter.  Our field engineer found a few stormwater basins in the area that needed cleaning and our Sewer Operation crews for Preventative Maintenance have cleaned out these structures.

While we believe that a continual overlay of pavement over the years has contributed to the ponding stormwater at this intersection, we are still looking at some financially feasible options to help reduce standing water at this location. We discussed this matter with the City’s Department of Public Works (DPW) at our monthly meeting this week and have asked their engineer to investigate what options DPW might have to help get positive drainage down to the nearest curb inlet.  Installing a new catch basin in the roadway would be very expensive and there are numerous other issues that can be addressed that have more serious public safety concerns at this time.

We will follow up with DPW in the near future and let you know what possible improvements can be applied to this issue.

Thank you.


Jim ____________
City of Atlanta | DWM | Project Manager
Office of Engineering Services | Strategic Asset Management Division
72 Marietta Street, NW | Atlanta, GA 30303 | 6th floor
Office 404-546-3693 | Cell 770-294-2045

No date specified for other options for positive drainage at this T-intersection. This T-intersection adjacent to preschool where families must walk into oncoming East-West traffic while morning drivers are blinded by morning sun. 

#amirfarokhi #jaytribby #candlerparkneighborhoodorganization #candlerparkdaypreschool
I wrote to SWIT team four days ago asking for update. Haven't heard back.

Yesterday's email from the SWIT team (Stormwater Investigative Team) 5/25/18: 

"While we do have some limited MOST funding for stormwater projects, we have already allocated the most recent funding to projects that were in the queue quite a long time ago, and are still addressing issues that have a more severe impact to the drainage and protection of the roadways.  We did have our team has inspect the drainage inlets in the same area and did find some that needed cleaning, so we then referred this work to our DWM crews to have the structures cleaned out. 

In spite of our efforts to clean the stormwater basins along this area, we believe that this matter is better addressed by the City’s Dept. of Public Works (DPW), to help address roadway paving options that can better help to drain this specific area.  Installation of new stormwater inlets and pipes would for this one area would be very costly and not the most effective use of the limited funding we have available.

We will remind DPW about this issue and see if they can directly respond as to their options and schedule to assist in resolving this matter."

Following up on next best (cheaper) option: paving to nearest inlet. Just sent an email reminder today asking if a DPW paving date has been scheduled. Unfortunately all the years of complaints to previous City Council were lost and this issue never got in the MOST queue.  Last I heard from SWIT team on this issue was from 5/25/18, where it was last on the DPW's plate. This is an issue that cannot and WILL NOT get lost in the shuffle. It becomes a mosquito breeding ground days after even a light rain. #amirfarokhi #candlerparkneighborhoodorganization

Received a reply from the SWIT team that Commissioner Johnson had assigned this issue to Cotena Alexander who is now out of town until July 10, 2018. Per the email vacation notice, I have emailed Walabi@atlantaga.gov this entire thread and asked him for a date. The issue is that this intersection is the entrance to a dead end street. The neighbors on this street need plenty of advance notice or they will not be able to get out. Can we have a scheduled date for street resurfacing to nearest inlet?

I should correctly say, "positive drainage to nearest inlet" instead of resurfacing because as was pointed out, continual overlay of pavement is what probably contributed to historic ponding in the first place. That, and not having a storm drain.
Thanks for the update. Please allow them time to review what you've sent and they should get back to you with more information.
Commissioner Johnson appointed someone specific on DPW as the point person on 3/16/18. I've contacted that office and sounds like they will look into it now.
Thanks for staying on top of this!
Thank you, this has been a frustrating experience, and I regret my tone above. I hope the drainage does work smoothly and appreciate everyone who has worked hard to research all possible avenues.

One time a guy robbed another guy outside the liquor store at the corner of Semmes and Washington Road.  He then ran down Semmes street and ran left onto this section of Westwood, with the police not too far behind.  He ran behind this house in question on this posting, and disappeared.  

There were more cop cars than you could imagine within about 10 minutes.  They canvassed the area, and finally determined the guy had run into this house.

They surrounded the house and yelled at him with a megaphone to come out.  Then they waited.  Finally, they gave up and left.

I asked one of the officers why didn't they just go in the house and get the guy, and I was told the house was unsafe for officers to go into, that the flooring was rotted out in some places, and he didn't want to risk his officers safety pursuing this subject into such a property.

That was several years ago.

The police are the code enforcement in East Point.  And yet to date nothing has been done.

Here is my prediction:  nothing is going to get done this time either.

comment_text: ATL311 - This is on private property.

Hey McGill Board, I think you guys may have misunderstood the purpose of seeclickfix.  This is intended as a public tool to complement the 311 process (lots of other cities have it integrated into their 311, e.g. Decatur).  It's a bit confusing having requests for a privately owned property mixed in with requests for publicly managed spaces.

In case there is a feature for this, maybe set your property's requests to private and give your tenants permission to view them?

SCF is a public app. That said, our association is in the process with SCF to obscure our records from the public side. ATL311 will need to ignore us over the next 45-60  days like they do with all the other requests submitted either through SCF or ATL311.

Good deal, thanks for the reply. I’ve been thinking of ways to help ATL311 through this app. Agreed they could use some improvements, and integrating w/ open311 would be a great way to keep up with some cities that are way ahead of us with tech innovation

Contact Rocky Atkins  (roatkins@atlantaga.gov) the 311 Exec Director. He has made changes, and I agree the city is way behind. Several GA cities use SCF and us as an HOA have found it cost effective to use.

comment_text: Decatur Public Works - J Maximuk assigned this issue to Decatur Public Works - M Hirose

I was a part of the initiative to put the stop sign in at Beatty. And have been a part of several traffic calming meetings. As I’m not sure who this is, I don’t want to offend. But as one who lives at that intersection, I must say that the traffic has been better since that hump was removed. We have been seeing less hostile driving and less speeding around to pass on the left. Most city planners will tell you that adding speed bumps, especially as severe as that one was, can in fact create more hostile driving. At any rate, it’s a discussion to be had as part of a larger initiative for Second Ave.

Kathryn, perhaps better at your location on 2nd, however, what it has done towards Oakview is made it very difficult to even get out of one's driveway during peak traffic, not to mention the much higher speeds attained by the commuters(it's all down hill from Oakview towards Beatty). In addition to the stop sign at the intersection of Beatty and 2nd, there is a speed bump two houses towards East Lake which keeps traffic very slow on that portion of 2nd, even though the stop sign attenuates the issue in that location.
I recall signing your petition for the stop sign after the near fatal situation with the bicyclist who ran the stop sign from Beatty and the irony of that is the bicyclists still don't stop for the stop sign!

Kathryn Johnson:  I support the stop sign but like John said beyond the intersection people hit the gas and speed unabated from Oakview to the stop sign and from the stop sign to Oakview.  There needs to be something that mitigates speeding along that stretch because it is a safety issue with so many children on the sidewalks on this block.  This isn't an either/or situation and there are two speed humps on the other side of the Beatty intersection on 2nd.  

I'm sincerely happy to have you over to my porch so you can see this issue from my vantage point.  John you're welcome as well.
Writing again to follow up on this item.  What is the process for addressing these issues that are left open this long?
Customer Care assigned this issue to MDeberry
020518- Thank your for your concern.  This property is listed on the Clean City Initiative program.  It is in the process of a Court action.  Open investigation.

I hope these stripes are *never* applied. 
It is not at all clear, that is, what *safety* purpose they would serve.

When cities double-yellow neighborhood streets like this they send the following message: drivers should treat this road as if it is a highway. This is where these double-yellow lines belong -- highways.
Neighborhood streets should receive as little striping and as few signs as possible.

Study after study (not that anyone cares about facts) have shown that the *fewer* the road treatments applied, the safer the street. It does sound counter-intuitive. The lack of striping affects driving behavior toward the more-cautious, which should always be the goal.
Thank you for alerting us to this matter. The painting may be forthcoming, but DEC will check into the status of this issue.

Agree. This is an enormous public safet issue. It is a hazard for traffic that must swerve around them in a location near a street crossing that makes it a pedestrian hazard. Many of the pedestrians are from the hospital clinic, many are diasabled on motorized scooters. Still more pedestrians cross this section of the street midblick as jaywalkers going to the housing authority and the Kroger. 

This was a poor architecture decision in the 1960s to allow super block buildings that were allowed to build tall and right up to the property line without setbacks allowing for on-site deliveries on a surface lot. This zone is a hazardous set of issues that on-street loading only makes worse. 

The answer is for the upper deck parking garage to be 'sliced back' ( the lid taken off the ground level service drop off that exists) so that trucks can not have a clearance problem ) .These office buildings are commercial ventures, they should be made to keep their functions so they don't cause safety hazards, and loaded no is a cost of doing business.
I agree with th prior comment.  Deliveries could also be made through the upper level terrace lot for these buildings.

Jaywalking and scootering is a separate issue, also needing an ordinance and enforcement.  There are 3 chronic jaywalking sites in this area: Commerce between medical buildings and Kroger, Commerce between Baptist parking and offices on Church corner, and Church between state services buildings and Bank of America Lot.  I have seen many people jaywalking less than 20' from a corner and marked crosswalk. The scooters move fast and are a special hazard.  When I get pictures I will post.

There is a jaywalking ordinance.  How would you propose to enforce it?
What kind of scooter ordinance would you like to see?  Thy are motor vehicles driven by licensed drivers and can only be driven on the street.
Sounds like you need to talks to your City Commissioners.

I would propose that Decatur Police issue citations to jaywalkers under the existing ordinance.  I think we confused the definition of "scooter".  I think the prior commenter meant "motorized wheelchairs, aka mobility chairs" not 2-wheeled motor scooters, and I know I meant that.  The latter scooters are motor vehicles but I doubt the motorized chairs are.  I propose that jayscootering be cited under the jaywalking ordinance. If the ordinance exists I don't know what more to say to commissioners beyond encourage police enforcement, and will do that.

It's a phased solution. The jaywalking should ultimately be addressed (like it is in urban centers around the US, and in Improvement Districts like Midtown, Buckhead etc) with railings, street furniture and tree skirt fences along the sidewalk as required installations for the redevelopment projects that will occur along these linear blocks. This prevents random movements into the moving traffic lanes. In the interim, an education program must be developed for the area businesses (housing authority, DeKalb Medical, County parole office) to post signs and encourage reformed behaviors of their clients. And law enforcement starts with community policing and education too. Law enforcement needs input on what works best and how to get it done. But it needs to start sometime soon, it's a worsening problem and injuries are imminent

"I would propose that Decatur Police issue citations to jaywalkers under the existing ordinance."
They will if they observe it, but I'd rather have them spending time on crime instead of hanging out looking for jaywalkers.
Thank your for your comment on lane obstructions.  This issue has come up in the recent past and so DEC will start to pursue a solution.

I acknowledge the comments above and I understand the problems inherent in unloading a truck on Commerce and the problems involved in jaywalking. However, I live downtown and walk this area almost daily. It is VERY unfriendly to people who walk as their mode of transportation. Excessive speeding downtown is rampant, and my neighbors and I often fear for our lives as we try to cross a street by legal means. Let's not just concentrate on how to keep jaywalkers from jaywalking, but how to share the road. And that requires some SLOWING of the car traffic. We're all trying to get somewhere safely.

At that same intersection the house on the corner of Brookhurst and North Peachtree their hedge is protruding out into the sidewalk to the point that if you are trying to make a left turn from Brookhurst to North Peachtree you have to be over the crosswalk in order to see oncoming traffic. Peachtree Middle School kids are walking at that time of day (8:00 am hour) and if you are stuck in the crosswalk trying to see and a child comes up to cross over Brookhurst they either have to walk in N. Peachtree Street or behind the car.  Not a safe situation. Homeowner needs to drastically remove hedge from sidewalk area so that cars can easily see oncoming traffic. This problem "supposedly" was corrected but if it was it was not sufficient to be able to see traffic.

I concur with Mary's comment.  In order to see on-coming southbound traffic, I have to drive across the crosswalk at Brookhurst to see because the hedges are way too big and a sight block.  And I drive an SUV.   It also doesn't help that people are parking at this intersection on both sides in the No Parking zones.  I've called Dunwoody Police numerous mornings this semester, but not sure if they are giving tickets.  I've gotten shoulder shrugs when I tell people they are parked illegally.
A prioritized work order is in place for this issue. Repairs will take place according to their priority. Thank you for your patience.
The city is considering many solutions, including this one, to improve morning traffic on North Peachtree Road.

This is good to hear!  Can we utilize the new Dunwoody Citizen Patrol to provide warnings to those parking illegally or using our driveways as turn arounds?  The past couple of years, once people got a few tickets, everyone tended to park away from the intersection on their own (but still had the occasional violator). 

For the bushes at 2262 Brookhurst, I see that GDOT's manuals suggest that a driver with eye height 3.5' feet above the ground should be able to see a car 390' away (both to the left and right) at 15' back from the curb, for a 2-lane road with a 35mph speed limit.  We can't even see 10 feet.  If these bushes can't be maintained by the homeowner at 3.5', then they need to be moved or removed.  Kids having to walk between cars that are forced to ease into the intersection just to see is dangerous and some of these kids are short enough to "disappear".  I think children's safety should outweigh an individual's right to obstruct sight distance.  If this were a fence, these heights would never be allowed.

Actually, the bikes have been there for YEARS. I've lived on Adair for 11 years and for the first month I lived here, I thought the Mormons were visiting him.  I think the real solution to this problem is to change the "no parking" from the east side of the street to the West side of the street.  This serves two needs: 1. the homeowner no longer has to worry about people trampling on his yard/garden or parking in front of his house and 2. it allows those visiting Adair Park to park on the same side of the street as the park (where there's a sidewalk -- there isn't a sidewalk on the West side of Adair whereas there is a sidewalk on the East side.)  This would be SO MUCH SAFER for parents and their children.  I, however, do not know what the process is for having this idea heard and acted upon.
Agreed. YEARS

Megan J - that's a great idea! Not sure of process either, but when Melrose Ave. was moved to single side parking, the approvals went through the City Commission. Looks like the next meeting is on Monday, the 17th? I would bring this idea to their attention to see what options exist.

Yes, they've been blocking that spot with unused bikes for at least 9 years. I don't know if it's legal or not. It's a valid parking spot, and very convenient to Adair Park. Switching the side of the street you can park on is a pretty solid idea, I think.
Agreed. Seems like a very unwelcoming gesture for a Welcoming City!
Love the thoughtful solution
Megan, great idea! Change the parking to the sidewalk side.

The bikes being on the street actually make it easier and safer to drive. Since that house is just before the curve, if there is a car parked there you cannot see the oncoming car and there is no room to negotiate around the parked car. The owner's bikes parked in front of his own house help keep the flow of traffic smooth and safe. I dont understand the issue, would there be complaints if he parked his car there? Do his bikes prevent you form parking there in front of his house?
If only everyone would be considerate enough to block public parking spots with their bikes!

Thank you for your comment on the street lights along Ponce de Leon Ave.  City staff have been coordinating with Georgia Power for several months on the lighting conditions in this area and will continue communications till the work has been completed.
Would it be helpful if all of us downtown residents contact Georgia Power? We live downtown and need our neighborhood lighted at night to keep us safe.
Could we keep this open until it is solved---even if it is the responsibility of Georgia Power.
Georgia power is working on this.

A Decatur Minute story may be helpful in understanding why the lights have not been repaired:
"Several blocks of street lamps along Ponce de Leon Avenue near the Old Courthouse have been out for weeks. Georgia Power was working to find the cause and had isolated the problem to a faulty underground service line. Before they could start on a repair, they had to pull all of their crews to help restore power to south Georgia and adjacent states in the aftermath of hurricane Matthew. Georgia Power is now back on the project and we have been assured they will make it their top priority."

From: Oslund, Cheryl 
Sent: Tuesday, August 23, 2016 8:43 AM
To: hswtiter@aol.com
Subject: Request for Mowing

Good Morning Ms. Smith,

This is in response to your request for mowing on Lake Forrest Drive.  I apologize that you have had difficulty getting a response.   We do strive to provide quality customer service to our residents, so I will look into what caused the delay and make sure we improve our response time in the future.  

Lake Forrest Drive is on our list of secondary routes, which means it gets mowed 4 times during the growing season.  The last time it was mowed was on July 1st.  The 3rd phase of mowing started last week, and I have confirmed that Lake Forrest Drive is on the schedule to be mowed this week, weather permitting.  I will have one of our Field Superintendents follow up, to make sure it was completed.   Just to let you know, the 4th phase of mowing will be in October. 

Please feel free to contact me with any additional questions or concerns.  

Thank you, 

Cheryl Oslund
Administrative Coordinator, Field Services
City of Sandy Springs
7840 Roswell Road, Building 500
Sandy Springs, GA  30350
Phone: (770) 730-5600  Fax:  (770) 206-2578

What needs to be verified is if the animal waste produced by the dogs the owner is "petsitting" or "kennelling" is flowing into Peachtree Creek behind the house during rainfall. 

Interestingly, at the intersection of Geneva/Lucerne/Champlain, Dekalb County has posted a yellow sign reporting a sewage spill. The property at 311 Willow runs downhill towards the Peachtree Creek. The residences on the other side back up to the creek where the sign is posted. If numerous dogs are kenneled here at 311 Willow, especially during weekends/holidays, how can the owner control where dog waste goes? If it smells like dog waste when walking past the property, then surely there is dog waste flowing to the creek when it rains. This is disgusting and unsafe for our environment, especially our creeks feeding into public parks where children wade barefoot during warm weather.

I think this warrants a full investigation on how the owner is using his property at 311 Willow Lane. Please take the time to walk in front of this property. Would you live next to this house?

Mr. Maximuk, As someone who has lived on Norris Street for over thirty five years, may I suggest that the problem is not that the road is poorly maintained.  The road, a one lane dirt/gravel "turkey path" (Mr. Clyde Davidson's description, who lived on the corner of Norris and Church for more than fifty years) that is the last remaining Civil War era street in Decatur, was not designed to handle the hundreds of soccer mommies and daddies that choke the road on the weekends. May I suggest that you either designate the road "residents only" during the weekend, forcing soccer parents to walk the 100 yards from Church Street parking spaces or what I favor, which is "Do Nothing".  The condition of the road forces people to slow down thereby making the park safer for walking children and their parents.  Drivers do a pretty good job navigating the road without the help of the police or other government workers.  Oh, one more thing, the tree trunk in the middle of the end of road parking lot is all that remains of the keep to the right swing around that helped vehicles move through the area.  Why the city cut it down is beyond my level of comprehension but that's another topic.  Chris Billingsley
Decatur Public Works - A Jackson assigned this issue to Decatur Public Works - J Maximuk

Mr. Billingsley -

Thank you for your comment. I will commit to looking at this issue and observing the weekend flow on Norris Street.  If you would like to describe this in more detail, please contact me at the office at 678.553.6570.  I would be happy to talk with you. 

John  Maximuk

Mr. Maximuk-
So is the condition of Norris Street acceptable to the City of Decatur or not?  If not, when will it be remedied?
*brian w jones
I have not been able to make a determination.  I will look into this by June 17.   John Maximuk 678.553.6570
Status please?
We will look at this area of concern.
Progress?

We're still waiting for an answer. The problem Mr. Billingsley states is only part of the problem. Those soccer Mums & Dads won't use Norris Street, so they drive through the Decatur Square Condos private property at break-neck speed, endangering the resident homeowner/taxpayers who live there, not to mention the wear and tear on the asphalt.

This issue has been received by the City of Sandy Springs. Your Service Request number is 16-025782

From: Oslund, Cheryl 
Sent: Wednesday, May 11, 2016 1:57 PM
To: figgeneral@gmail.com
Subject: Report of Water Leak and Broken Sidewalk on Roswell Road

Good Afternoon,    

This is in response to your report of the water leak and the broken sidewalk on Roswell Road.   The address that came through for the water leak on SeeClickFix does not match the picture of the leak, so I just want to confirm that the leak is near the BB&T Bank.  

With regards to the sidewalk, because there is a water leak at this location, we cannot repair the sidewalk until the leak has been repaired.  With that said, the City of Atlanta (COA) has jurisdiction for the water infrastructure in the City of Sandy Springs.   We have reported both of these water leaks to the City of Atlanta. 

In the event that you would like to report these leaks as well, below is the contact information for reporting water meter leaks to the City of Atlanta.   When reporting the leak, be sure to get a ticket number and to reference this number each time you contact COA about the leak.   

 To report a leaking or damaged water meter, please call the Department of Watershed Management Customer Service at 404-546-0311, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Following  is the link to the City of Atlanta website, regarding report of leaking or broken water meters:  http://www.atl311.com/?page_id=115&atlId=1-4NTBC&_crauth=85ac1e5a03

Please feel free to contact me if you have any additional questions or concerns.   

Thank you, 

Cheryl Oslund
Administrative Coordinator, Field Services
City of Sandy Springs
7840 Roswell Road, Building 500
Sandy Springs, GA  30350
Phone: (770) 730-5600  Fax:  (770) 206-2578

This issue has not been addressed to date. In addition to the missing concrete wall/exposed rebar, the directional street sign is falling into the creek below, leaving DeKalb County wide open for a lawsuit if an accident happens that is caused by the lack of a clear directional sign. Also, due to a repeated number of accidents, the both sides of the creek near the railroad tracks need to be cleared of miscellaneous road debris. Thank you for your prompt attention.

This issue is still outstanding. The only change is that the weeds have grown taller, hiding the orange cones that were put in place to alert drivers of the missing portion of the wall. Please trim the weeds near the cones and on both Frazier side of the railroad tracks. Both sides of the road, including the sidewalk side, is so overgrown with weeds, pedestrians are in peril.
Four months since this was reported and nothing has happened except the weeds have grown taller; the orange cones are barely visible now.

The issue has not been addressed. The orange cones went missing recently. The weeds grew so high, a neighbor knocked them back when his wife complained about visibility. If you check police records, you will find that another car accident took place at this intersection within the last month; the car ended upside down but I saw no further damage to the barrier wall. See attached photo of how the wall appears now.
After 421 days, this issue has still not been addressed!

This was a GDOT intersection re-painting job. They did not bother (or could not be bothered) with such trivialities as signals and signage. I emailed with them for about six months before they eventually removed the "Right Lane Right Turn Only" signs posted next to the opposite-side bike lane from this photo. I mean: if you use your 22 to disable all the lights in this signal, someone will probably mend them . . . but they'll likely just remain stupid, as they are now. My (un)favorite part of this intersection is the pedestrian signal for those crossing eastbound from Park across East Lake. Just for (un)fun, one day try to use that crosswalk east-bound. There is a ped. signal there . . . really there is. I saw them install that new device about two years ago. Rocket science, apparently.
Acknowledged

To clarify my earlier, pretty negative comment: The striping and lack of signage was, and is, a GDOT project, and the ridiculous pedestrian signal was installed by a Dekalb County crew.

As far as I know, our fair city had no part in this. That said, City of Decatur administrators (and crews) have always been prompt to respond and even proactive with other agencies when an issue arises. Maybe they can help remedy this whole thing.

Difficult to understand a safety issue here. 
Stopped motor traffic at Olympic should *cautiously* and safely enter the intersection at College when school children are present. Unless, of course, motorists have something better to do than operate their 3,000-pound conveyance in a safe and cautious manner. I am sure that is not you, however. Always vigilant and always cautious, surely.
To be clear: roadway traffic signals are a *safety* device not a license to drive as if others are simply “in the way” or in need of containment. The first safety device is the operator. Caution, that is, is always an option.

Also, crosswalk signals should be at about the bottom of city roadway priorities. It would be difficult to find any study showing added safety via crosswalk signals.

p.s. I regularly use this crosswalk and have noticed exactly zero danger being posed by those a-foot. The deadly danger posed by motorists, however, is imminent and inescapable.

I would encourage you to look more closely at what happens at this particular intersection: while motorists who live on Olympic do understand what limited visibility we have coming off the street and do use caution, the motorists who are too impatient to wait for the left turn onto Atlanta Ave from College, turn into Olympic, turn around and wait in the shorter queue to travel across the tracks do not. Additionally, pedestrians fail to take into consideration that they need to stop when the lights for College AND Olympic are red because there is occasional thru traffic that crosses the tracks on Atlanta Ave and travels onto Olympic; these motorists also have limited visibility if a pedestrian has just stepped into the crosswalk as they are coming through the intersection and continuing on Olympic. 

I flagged this as a safety issue because the traffic patterns at this particular intersection are confusing to those adults not familiar with the intersection and totally baffling to children who use that crosswalk without so much as a glance across the tracks to confirm the absence of oncoming cars to Olympic! 

John Maximuk has been on Olympic and observed the dangers posed by this intersection first hand. The residents of Olympic are encouraged by the involvement of the City, but we hope to keep the issue at the forefront of the City to ensure pedestrian safety at this particular intersection.

And if unfamiliar with the light pattern there is no way for pedestrians to anticipate how much time they have for crossing before the light for Olympic place turns green and they can be caught inn the middle off the intersection.  
Yes drivers should be careful nobody is suggesting otherwise, but I think that misses the fundamental point that a 5 way intersection that is designated as a safe route to school for multiple surrounding schools, on a busy state road, should reasonably at a minimum have walk signals in all cross walks.

This intersection does have unique challenges and this is why we have studied modifying both sides of this intersection. In order for me to better understand your concern, would you please call me, David Junger, 404-377-5571?

Your time is appreciated,

David

Please contact me to discuss this request. Requests for new traffic control devices are handled separately from traffic signal issues. I can be reached at 404-377-5571 David Junger

A petition for an all-way stop at this intersection has been submitted by residents of the area.  City staff have conducted site visits at all locations, and engineering staff are currently working to determine if these locations are warranted under the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD).  This is the guiding document for all engineering issues related to traffic control.  The City must ensure that the addition of any new controls can be supported under these guidelines. 

City staff will also be reaching out to staff and parents in the City Schools of Decatur, as 3 all-way stops have been proposed in the vicinity of the 4/5 Academy. 

We appreciate your patience and I will keep you informed as things progress.

Dekalb, what is the problem that we can't seem to keep the local road repairs up to par.  Why put a bandaid on the issue, just repave the entire street, please.  Georgia received $900 million in road/transit infrastructure March 2015 that the President signed off on this year.  Why is there more emphasis on the highways than the local roads?  Dekalb transportation committees, GDOT, and  DeKalb Public works and Drainage Div. should be ashamed of themselves. 

Location: E. Conley Rd. Conley, Ga., Dekalb County

"The DeKalb Public Works, Roads and Drainage Division conducts
an annual inspection of 2,280 miles of County roadway
as part of its pavement management system. Roads were
scored using GDOT’s rating system where overall scores
do not exceed 60 points; a pavement is considered to need
major reconstruction if determined to have 30 or more points".

This is a valid complaint. The main dumpster banging takes place at the rear of the Food Market & car repair/sales next to the market. The refuse driver slams the steel dumpster into the truck hopper six to eight times. This issue would go away if he altered his pickup time a bit later. Everyone is up by 6 or 7 AM and traffic is still lite. 4 to 4:30 AM slam banging isn't fair to the neighborhood.

So today is TUESDAY, March 24th and it happened again - this time at 3:15AM.  How can that trash collector get away with making so much noise so early in the morning?  Please send a police car to monitor this area on Tuesdays & Thursdays between the hours of 3AM - 4:30AM, please catch this guy violating the local noise ordinanace and make him stop.
Happened again this week at 3:45AM.
Banging continues around 4 AM that can be heard for at least a square mile. Trash company adjusted dumpster pickup times for a couple weeks then returned to this disturbing hour again.
Still happening - this is CRAZY!  I can't believe that this garbage collection company hasn't been issued a NOISE CITATION.
Happened again at 4:30AM - Tuesday, March 15.  Got a quick video of the truck leaving, but no BANG, BANG, BANG - I couldn't make it out the door fast enough.
Garbage Collection and banging still continues every week - VERY loud banging between the hours of 3AM and 5AM.

4:15AM - Monday, May 16th - Still banging those business dumpsters at the QUICK STOP Food Mart and the AUTO REPAIR Center.  Please issue them a noise citation.  Why does the whole neighborhood have to be woken up so early from this noise?  Please STOP this company from collecting garbage outside of normal business hours.

Let's stay on top of this issue till someone does something about it. Even if it takes a visit to those business establishments and having the proprietors contact their garbage company as a good neighbor.
The City of Doraville does have a noise ordinance governing commercial garbage pickup between 10 PM and 6 AM adjacent to residential neighborhoods. Someone of authority needs to contact Waste Pro.
For pete's sake - they are back at it.  4:30AM bangs across the street.  How does the city let them get away with this noise?  Make them STOP!!!

I received this message posted today on the Nextdoor Morningside/Lenox Park forum.

Many drivers are confused and don't know what to do at HAWK pedestrian signals.   How will they be educated?   Please see the posting below:
 	
<Neighbor>, Morningside/Lenox Park

I've called and written the DOT with no response except that they "don't have enough information." When the cross light for pedestrians near Monroe and Piedmont turns solid red, obviously one must stop for the pedestrian who needs to cross. Then the light starts flashing red. It's red, so I think red means stop and I wait until it has completely turned off before driving on. I am frustrating drivers behind me who honk if the flashing signal starts and I continue to sit there as I do. I in turn feel frustrated by the drivers who start driving despite the flashing red.
I don't know what the lawful thing to do is. Here is the link to the GA traffic laws regarding traffic signals.
http://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2010...
In this section of the code, a steady red signal is referenced, as is a red arrow, but no mention can I find of a flashing red signal.
I ran into another flashing red signal today at Mt. Paran and Lake Forrest. It's a 4 way stop and there is a constant red flashing signal in all four directions. I assumed that is to point out to people that it is a 4 way STOP and they are to respect the STOP sign. As in 4 way stops, traffic stops for the stop sign and go in turn, so they are driving through the flashing red signal.
Anyone know what to do?
Thanks,

Thank you for taking the time to report this issue.  Midtown Alliance is a non-profit organization working to improve the Midtown Community.   While basic infrastructure repair and maintenance remain the responsibility of the City of Atlanta, our full-time staff works to enhance these services in the district.  To this end, we address outstanding issues as quickly as we can and as our budget and authority allow.  For those issues that lie outside of our purview, we will advocate for resolution on your behalf. If this is in reference to a turn signal on Moreland for Hardee then I completely agree.
Service request 179941111 has been submitted for a traffic study at this intersection.
Solution Topic: Traffic Study

comment_text: Service request 179941111 has been closed and it has been determined that a left turn signal is not warranted at the intersection of Moreland and Hardee ST for the northbound or southbound direction. This request was made earlier this year, with a count and study performed in late January 2017 and again this month. An inspection of the intervals in the AM and PM peak hours show no increase in southbound or northbound turn volumes. The current volume of turns at this intersection along with the low crash rate are sufficiently below the levels of warranting a turn signal light at this intersection. We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause.
Solution Topic: Traffic Study

comment_text: This yard debris winds up in our stormwater system.
Stormwater engineer spoke with a citizen regarding the issue. City staff will monitor the issue. Thanks for reporting.
What is the proper protocol when a citizen sees a lawn crew blowing leaves and debris into the street or a storm drain?  I see it all the time...who do you call or report that laziness to?

Take a picture and send it Cassundra Huntley  
Daytime Phone: 404-637-0570 
After Hours*: 404-637-0555 
Email: cassundra.huntley@brookhavenga.gov
Thanks...

@ Tom - Stormwater violations include, but are not limited to, sediment running off of construction sites, spills and dumping of chemicals, fuels or any other non-stormwater materials, including trash and/or leaves, into the storm sewers. 

If you observe a stormwater violation you would like to report to the City, please submit the issue via the city’s SeeClickFix web application or contact the Brookhaven Code Enforcement Manager, Cassundra Huntly, utilizing the contact info KathieCoy provided above. 

Thank you!

comment_text: The first step is to determine whether the tree(s) in question are within the City's Right-of-Way or not. If they are, then it would be the City's responsibility to maintain them, however if they are on private property, it is the responsibility of the property owner to maintain their tree(s). I have assigned this issue to Public Works to verify ownership of the trees. Once that is established, we can determine next steps. Thank you!

comment_text: Left turns onto Caldwell used to be allowed from Oaklawn Ave and Sunland Drive.  The traffic was ridiculous.  Unfortunately, drivers would race down these residential streets at high speeds. This made the area unsafe for children.  Not sure why East Osborne was made into a one way.  This should be changed so the left turn onto Caldwell ismade there. That street is not a residential street.

The no left turns from Oaklawn and Sunland made some sense when it was first enacted, but those times are long past. Unfortunately, if left turns are allowed, those streets are again going to get slammed with speeders. I feel for those homeowners as they'll probably be forced to pay for speed humps. To the city -- go out there during rush hour and look how many people illegally make the left turn. With no enforcement it's a risk that pays off for them to bypass the near gridlock on Dresden. Also, if you're looking at changing things on Oaklawn and Sunland, what about doing something about the valet parking situation at Kaleidoscope? And better timing of traffic lights at Caldwell? There are lots of moving pieces to the traffic mess and they all need to be looked at together, not separately.

True - definitely too many people speeding as is and wouldn't want to encourage it more. I agree with PG, ideally the whole system in that area needs to be re-evaluated to try and find some logical solution.

It's awful how many people disregard the "No Left Turn" sign from Sunland onto Caldwell and end up cruising through at high speeds.  As a long time resident, I see it every day and am thankful I'm not walking with my young children at the time.  A permanent re-opening of that intersection would be disastrous.  Meanwhile, why should I have to pay for speed bumps when I'm already paying for a new local government that should be enforcing (or at least reinforcing) its traffic control?

Agree with the racing down Oaklawn Ave -- but No legal left hand turn has NOT deterred traffic traveling Apple Valley Road and cutting across Oaklawn Ave and Sunland to Caldwell and turning left on Caldwell.  This has been reported for YEARS and the county does nothing about it-- 9 out of 10 cars passing my house make illegal left hand turns!!  We asked for speed bumps-- now limited exit.  Naturally the county planning people knew best-- without consulting the neighborhood.  One more time-- either enforce the illegal left hand turn at the end of the street-- or take it out and put in speed bumps!!  Brookhaven police don't care-- they sit right there- or better yet sit in J Cristopher's drinking coffee-- and do nothing to enforce this area.  Yes-- the traffic is deplorable on Dresden-- but that is what develops are all about-- the neighborhoods are left to figure it out for themselves.

As a resident in this area, The volume and speed of which traffic comes through these streets is absurd. Speeding, illegal turns are the norm. And that is with the clearly marked No Left Turn.  These are residential streets, not "cut-throughs," which our tax bills will surely substantiate. 

I agree with the earlier comment about East Osborne, which used to the a 2-way street that does not have residences. Can this be pursued as a route to stop the illegally turning traffic in Sunland and Oaklawn?
commenter_name: resident of the area in question

comment_text: Whether to get speed tables installed or not is entirely up to the residents of the street. Do some research, initiate the process, do the legwork, get it done if that's what you want. Don't expect some all-powerful entity, whether county or city, to do it for you.
No. These neighborhoods will be trashed by the cut through traffic.
I don't know if the code requires a paved driveway or not, but it does require that any vehicles on the property must be running, tagged, and insured.

comment_text: Dekalb Co. has been called no less than 6 times regarding fallen tree waste at a different location…they have yet done anything!!!  Since we became "Brookhaven"  we get ZERO service with our tax dollars! The city gives the homeowner notice and threatens them with fines, the county shirks it's responsibility and who gets screwed?  You got it!… THE TAXPAYER!  Thanks Brookhaven citizens…you were so smart to vote for more government!

Why won't Brookhaven intercede on our behalf? They need to step up and support the residents instead of passing the buck over and over...

Are the people from "City of Brookhaven City Manager's Office" actually here in Brookhaven? Why aren't they more effective at resolving this ongoing litany of problems?

Get it together city employees - you wanted this job - time to do it.

I completely agree with one comment above. For decades County Sanitation picked up just about anything placed at the curb, whether is was cut up according to their rules or not. Since becoming the City of Brookhaven, the County Sanitation Dept.'s service has become mediocre at best. Is this some kind of payback from the County for voting in the City of Brookhaven?  Perhaps our City Manager, Marie Garrett should ruffle a few County feathers.
The property in the picture above is owned by none other than DEKALB COUNTY !!  Purchased in September by Dekalb County / FEMA Flood Mitigation Buyout Program.

This issue was initially described as a missed sanitation pickup. In this scenario, the property owner would in fact be responsible for contacting DeKalb County directly to arrange for pickup. With approximately 49,000 residents in the city, unfortunately, we do not have the manpower to reach out to DeKalb County for every missed residential sanitation pickup. 

I appreciate Mr. Walker providing clarifying information regarding this property. He describes this as a non-residential parcel owned by DeKalb County. More than likely, it is the result of tree work from their own crews. I will be glad to have our Public Works Department reach out to them to find out when they plan to dispose of the debris. I will leave this issue in ACKNOWLEGED status until we get a firm date. 

Thank you!
commenter_name: City of Brookhaven City Manager's Office
