comment_text: Lola, One of the speed bumps is right at the stop sign, and I believe that is not allowed according to DOT Rules. The signs that you speak of are not readily visible and only the eastbound side has one sign that is not close enough to the speed bump. They are also supposed to be clearly marked, because even going at the speed limit, your car jumps and an unsuspecting driver could lose control. As for me I drive at the speed limits or less. My father was a policeman so he taught me well!

Having posted signs for speed bumps is also the Law. What one driver did should not jeopardize all other drivers. If the police also gave out citations to drivers who do not properly signal for turns and lane changes, there would also be much less accidents and injuries. Not using turning signals will make you fail a Driver's Test in Georgia.
Was this problem fixed? Brookhaven acknowledged it over a year ago!
No longer used by Brookhaven, see CitySourced
Don't waste your time with CitySourced until we have a system in place with accountability; currently many issues are simply ignored.

This issue was reported by Midtown Alliance staff.  Please note that the Midtown Alliance uses SeeClickFix to track and manage repair issues and, in many cases, will voluntarily address these issues to supplement City services.  In other cases, we will coordinate with the City to accomplish these repairs.
LoL!  You get them and you're complaining. I would love giant speed humps on my street!  I have been begging for them.

I concur that these new speed humps are improperly installed. Its not just Woodrow Way. Drive on Hermance and you will see that Whatever pavement company Brookhaven hired also installed a couple of  improperly designed steep new ones in addition to keeping most of the existing properly designed (By Dekalb Stree Dept) ones.It is quite the contrast. The original ones (dozens are located throughout Brookhaven and neighboring communities)work great forcing drivers to keep speed within posted limit. The new ones are too high and steep forcing drivers to almost stop or buck them out of seats. the speed limit is 25 MPH. 
There is no reason to force cars to slow to 10MPH or stop  on Woodrow Way as there are no crosswalks in the area of speed humps. In fact their is a sidewalk with a generous buffer between it and the street on one side and a fenced property of Oglethorpe U on the other side. There is nothing to cross over to.
I also am concerned that these will delay Emergency vehicles responding to calls to my neighborhood. Minutes and seconds can make a difference.

I am complaining because the original speed humps worked perfectly. The new ones were installed by a lowest bid subcontractor hired by our new City Government. I am concerned that this shoddy workmanship will carry over to other Public Works projects. The street is not a private subdivision but a public street that feeds multiple neighborhoods. Its a direct route for Emergency vehicles to these neighborhoods also. I was at the original county meeting years ago when theses speed humps were proposed and the public was assured that these would be of the type that would allow ingress/egress at posted speed of 25 mph and not require a stop and roll. Look at all the other original properly installed ones on Hermance and Lanier drive.They work perfectly to curtail excessive speed yet allow smooth travel. I don't like to see our tax money wasted on shoddy workmanship. The company should be forced to redo the speed humps..

comment_text: Correct map location
At least all of those shrubs blocks the view of all the crap in the front and side yards!

If you took a moment to look at their yard, you'd see that the plants are amazing - the pillars are a little weird and the fountain may be a little oversized but the flowers are stunning. Their gardener does a great job keeping in season blooming flowers planted and faded blossoms pruned, I talk to him whenever I see him on my way home from the park. You obviously do not know this family or you'd understand their love of trees and plants. Not sure how you figure the trees are blocking the cross traffic, can't turn left on red and can't walk on don't walk light. I use this crosswalk everyday and my only problem are the idiots that drive onto the sidewalk to go around cars waiting to turn. The fire hydrant should be uncovered, even though it is clearly visible in the photo you provided because it may be overlooked in an emergency. As far as the bricks, they followed their property line inside the existing sidewalk. Yes, the city lays claim to a certain amount of our front yards but we homeowners are expected to maintain the property by mowing, trimming, planting flowers, shrubs, ,trees etc..

I checked the fire hydrant yesterday - it is not buried - there are two plants beside it can be easily relocated. It is visible when driving by as well as walking past it.  I will mention it to their yard guy the next time I see him.

I'm really lit up about this - they are the nicest family you could ever meet.  what is wrong with you people in brookhaven - too much concrete in this yard - too much greenery in that yard -  this person is flying flags and their concrete containers are touching the sidewalk - this guy has a van parked in his driveway that is ugly - goodness - not a very neighborly group of folks in this town.

Jimmie, I also appreciate their landscaping and the work they put into it.  Just because it is different and may not be their choice in plants I don’t understand complaining about it.  These want-a-bees that get all in your business over trivial issues really detract from the appeal of the area.  Just look at the number of votes this issue had received.

You know, it was our district one city council person that disliked what these people were doing to their own property and made the first complaint about this yard last year via SCF to code enforcement.  Disappointingly, there were several others that piled on with her in agreement with their own comments.  This tells you about the people living in this neighborhood and one of our city council members.
Rick - it is a shame our own council person would do that - I'll be sure and let them know.

Being the “nicest family you could ever meet” does not exempt a homeowner from abiding by the City’s code. Either their hardscape and plants are in the right of way or they are not. The City or County Fire Department can determine if the homeowner is encroaching or not. Facts dictate not how nice they are or what type of plants they enjoy. 
Is this the same nice family that also had their rear construction stopped for not having a building permit? Should they be given special building privileges as well?

And yes, the community as a whole is harmed when entire front lawns are paved, excessive numbers of commercial vans are parked on residential property, and planters are on sidewalks which are designed for walkers, joggers, bikers and people in wheelchairs.
 
If one doesn't wish to live by the City Code they should file for a variance or move to a community that has Ordinances they can live by.

The discussion is not about what they were building onto the back of their house - stay on track with the issue of their plants being in the right of way.  

A person has to be pretty fat or have a super wide stroller/wheelchair if they cannot get by this yard.

The plants and trees are not in the right of way - they are contained within their yard - the only true problem is they planted 2-4 plants too close to the fire hydrant.  

If you think this yard hurts our neighborhood - look up and down all of our streets - there are LOTS of grass, plants, trees, flowers, roses, etc. planted up to the sidewalk edge, including my yard - I have plants around my mailbox, in the strip between the street and sidewalk and my trees canopy 8 feet over the sidewalk.  Should they all be cut down - what a major hit our neighborhood would take and how barren it would be.

As previously stated, the "city" has a right to take a certain amount of our yards but we are fully expected to maintain it.  How about we all stop doing that, rake it all clean and pour concrete or dump gravel - it's the city's property - let them take care of it.  I've thought about doing that many times over the years.  

In my opinion, it seems that you are basing your issue based on what they were trying to do in their backyard which has already been handled because I cannot fathom why someone is so concerned about a brick touching the sidewalk.  

As far as everyone being harmed - what happens when the city allows the clear cutting of all trees - incuding specimen trees, grass, shrubs, flowers?  That is a huge hit to our community - I'd be more concerned about that in the big scheme of things.  

Regardless, I will let their gardener know about the bricks and the plants hiding the fire hydrant the next time I see them.

Can you insert a link specific to residential landscaping - I could not find anything on the City of Brookhaven site that specifically discusses what to do when I want to make changes to my yard - plant trees, shrubs, flowers, etc..

This property is a mess, with what appears to be multiple code violations.

Has any permits been applied for or are these so called improvements being done Illegally?

I say send in a county work crew and remove all the vegetation & bricks surrounding the public's fire hydrant and light pole---- paid for with taxpayers dollars.

Sure do that, tear it all out - go across the street to the two of the three corners and do the same, there is vegetation, bricks and trees by the light poles, then head up and down the street in every neighborhood and do the same.  Apparently you do not pay attention to our corners or you'd know that our neighborhoods were established long ago and many yards were here long before the light poles.  
If you are referring to building that was going on attached to the back of the house - stay on point - that was stopped long ago - certainally you already know that, so we do not know what improvements they were going to make.  
This is about their bricks being barely an inch onto the sidewalk and a few plants around the fire hydrant which is clearly visible and not covered in dirt - I am going by there Thursday on my way to the park, I will let them know the hydrant needs the plants and bricks removed from around it because the fire department may not see it in the dark and it should be kept clearly visible - a really easy task to accomplish.  I did laugh at the send in the COUNTY statement - remember we are not the county anymore.  We are the City of Brookhaven - I can't imagine them just walking in to someone's yard and start ripping out landscaping, that would be an awful thing to do.

I believe if the fire hydrant area needed to be cleared that would still be under the Dekalb Fire Department responsibility, however that could be a wrong assumption.

We can let the municipalities work with the homeowner to get in compliance.

Reports like this are a waste of time and money. Depending on the issue, it's a loss of freedom.  As with each new city created, the community begins to complain/report petty problems and reporting their neighbors like "tattle tells" with smartphones.

Well said Ian!  This is just terrible.  There is no code violation here whatsoever and there is no way those flowers and small plants are going to hinder the fire department.  People like Yankee have nothing better to do but point finger.  Look at SCF and you will see so many "Yankee" complaints.  Its terrible.  Jim Eyre was the same way.  Yankee, why dont you post your address and we can all come over there and complain about your property?

1. Shrubs are not illegal in right of ways.  Nor is grass.

2.  Landscape plans are not required in this instance

3.  Flowers can't hurt a fire hydrant

4.  This is stupid complaint and a complete waste of money for the city to investigate
Looks pretty to me. At least they keep their yard up. Plenty over here that do not.   Just sayin.
Glad to know I am not the only one that thinks this a ridiculous and time wasting report.
Everyone needs to check out what this "yankee" has been up to on this site.  It's scary. If I ever catch him taking pictures on my property or of my family I'm calling the police.
Brookhaven it's been since 7-17-2014 what is the resolve?

Yankee, 

There is clearly no violation here.  I think most reasonable people can see that, including Brookhaven.  It is not against code to landscape around a hydrant or against a sidewalk.  Do you have nothing better to do than drive around and take pictures of possible violations?  Maybe you get some sort of alternative hobby.

Barb (Guest)

Your are wrong :(     like your buddies Jimmie & Vince :)

Yankee (online bully),

If we are so wrong then why has nothing been done?  The point of this website is not to be an online bully, to be anoymously mean to neighbors who try their best to improve their landscape, hound the city/waste our tax dollars, or to make up codes that dont exist. I went back and looked at your complaints and the frequency and it really is crazy the amount of time and energy you spend on this stuff.  Taking pictures of children on a golf carts, grossly over exaggerating fence heights, making up erosion control issues, yelling about vans in a driveway.  Is this really your life?  Really? You have nothing better to do? Go back through this chain and read what people think of you, your complaints, your attitude and your behavior.  Then remember that you reap what you sow.
High 5 Barb!

Yankee - maybe you need some buddies - I think you are lonely.

Our yards were established LONG before we became a city - you may not be aware but we are fully expected to maintain any right of ways - free of charge.  All up and down Ashford Dunwoody, from 285 to Peachtree Industrial Blvd, there are multiple variations of landscaping on both sides of the road.   What do you expect to happen - all of it ripped out because we are a city now?  

I am concerned to see that you have allegedly taken pictures of children, that is scary on so many levels.

Barb and Jimmie, 

I hope you don't crash into the "children driving the golf carts" in the dark with out headlights.

You could be in the next "children " pictures you see.

Get a life and obey the laws of the land. If you don't like the laws change them---YOU don't get to pick n' choose.

Oh by the way don't complain when you get a ticket for traffic violations now that we are a City--you should obey those laws also.

High 5 that or just stroke each other........

I think thats enough Yankee.  This is a site for reporting problems, not making vastly inappropriate comments.  I have spoken to City of Brookhaven Code Enforcement and asked them to remove you from this site.  I have also contacted my neighbor whose home and children you were posting pictures of and made them aware of your actions on this site.  Odds are the police are now going to be involved.  I think the best thing you can do is just stay off of SCF.

Yankee - I will not be receiving traffic violations because I am the slow-poke actually adhering to the speed limit.  

If this is so important to you, take the time to go knock on the door of this home and inform the family of what you believe is wrong instead of posting rude things.  There is nothing wrong with being neighborly.  

Leaving the established landscaping in place is not picking and choosing laws to adhere to.

comment_text: Hey John, any new pictures to show?

I am also concerned about the height of the first floor of this new home. The threshold appears to be about 7 - 12 feet above the previous home's threshold. It was my understanding that builders had to take the average height of the previous home into consideration when building a new one.

Hmmm, is it the height or the setback that has to be taken into consideration? I think I had read that a house cannot be any closer to the street then it's neighbor's, but not sure there is a height restriction relative to the house next door.

There are zoning restrictions about setbacks and height in the R-75 classification. When they build a new house, they have to use the average of the previous home's threshold elevation - the one they tore down,  not the house next door - into account. The previous home was set much lower on the site, and it also appears the builder built up even the ground level with a mountain of dirt, so the threshold of the first floor is much higher than the previous home on the lot. It's also interesting that in the time between someone's complaint about the encroachment on the 7 1/2 foot side setback, the entire house has been built. What will Brookhaven do about this? Fine the builder and allow this to stand?
See Click Fix is not your best avenue for a fast resolution. Call Code Enforcement.
The builder has done nothing wrong. Brookhaven abolished the threshold requirement a long time ago

Sad but true: Brookhaven trashed the threshold requirement just like they have to all other constraints on development. This is why the builders have FLOCKED to our neighborhoods - they know that they can get away with it while the substitute teacher is in charge. 

If you really want Brookhaven's attention use their preferred bait: adult devices. Rumor has it they can hear a vibrator turning on at 100 yards.

I take recycling very seriously!  When I see the recycling bins in a disarray like this, I feel the city doesn't taking recycling too seriously.  I don't mind having to cart my things over to the bins but it appears that my conscientiousness is all in vein, considering most of the tainted bins will go to the garbage dump instead of through the proper recycling channels.  There are such things as remote cameras these days to monitor when someone is dumping their furniture and old tires at the bins.  You could also consider use a locking gate and issue codes to get in the gate to customers paying water / sewage bills.  Usually people who illegally dump are not paying for trash service.   Also, the locked gate may promote the idea that the bins are being monitored and those who are dumping illegally may not do it so freely.

comment_text: I feel like I am in the movie - Ferris Bueller's Day Off..."Brookhaven... Brookhaven... Brookhaven????" to no reply.

Have any of you checked to see if this home has a business license?  Or if they simply drive their work vehicles home and not run a business from the residence?  Or what the impervious lot calculation is?  My guess is no.  So much tax money wasted from people who have no idea what they are talking about

@Barbara - None of your items matter when the code clearly denotes what % a residential lot can have. This home is zoned residential, tax plot available online, percentage exceeds which was denoted in the previously opened item that was archived. My question is what is the city going to do going forward to prevent it. 

Unsure how any tax money is wasted when nothing has been done but do think the city needs to answer the above question, how is tax money going to be spent (not wasted) to ensure does not repeat?

Lastly, Barbara a sign about who is doing the work on the home has been in excess of 8+ months which also part of the code. Shall I research the owner of the company denoted in the company doing the work and compare to tax record which may be the same. 

You are right... some people do have no idea what they are talking about.

Nice job Douglas!  It is time for the "No Brookhaven" crowd to get over their defeat.  The majority of Brookhaven voters want to live in community where zoning laws and other Code provisions are enforced.  The city employs several Code compliance officers.  How is asking them to do their job and look into what apprears to be flagrant violations at this property a waste of taxpayer funds??

Regardless of if Barbara is anti-Brookhaven or not, the issue remains:

- Brookhaven has taken on the responsibility of creating statutes intended to reflect the will and desire of the residents and then enforcing those statutes.

- It's questionable if the current statutes are proper and it's questionable if they are being properly enforced.

Although this forum is not about the statutes themselves, it is definitely about enforcement. Brookhaven has not done a very good job when it comes to enforcement. The enforcement is inconsistent and often comes too late - or is too lenient.

Brookhaven does not have sufficient resources to properly enforce compliance. Brookhaven also does not have sufficient training in place to provide consistent and proper compliance.

The city appears to have outsourced much of their services and these problems are likely related to this cost-cutting approach to service. Unfortunately our neighborhoods are impacted by these fiscal decisions and we are unlikely to see an improvement if Brookhaven does not get its act together.

Doug, a couple things:

Since you seem to know so much can you tell me what percentage of the property is covered with impervious surface and the percentage that is covered by driveway?  Do you even know what that means and how this is calculated?  If you can, can you then tell me the exact zoning that dictates how much of that property can be covered by said impervious surface and how much they are in violation by? This means you need to provide more than the 35% listed above.  Also, please let me know, with 100% accuracy, if the city or county has issued any variances.  If so, please provide the variance number.

Can you tell me if that residence has pulled a home based business permit and is allowed to park vehicles for that business in the driveway?  Please provide the business license number issued by the city.  

Can you tell me if and when a building permit was pulled for any of this work and if it was approved by the city? Also provide what this permit was for and if it is still open. Please provide building permit number and the specifics of the permit.  Hint:  there was one pulled

The home next door (to the left) according to satellite, has about the same amount of driveway, including concrete that runs down the side of the house as well as two entrances to Ashford Dunwoody.  Please comment on why this house is not in violation and provide the lot calculations as well.

Hi Barbara

Your response inquiries to me are answers exactly why this inquiry was posted. As references, previously with no updates and archived. 

Back to my question what is the city going to do going forward to prevent it.  Code enforcement is not a waste of anyone's money nor is process validation. 

Appreciate your researching with the permit pulled even more why the city needs to answer. Residents shouldn't have to research as you so kindly did, the city process should be transparent and consistent. 

These are all fantastic questions that the city needs to answer about going forward. Thanks again for your efforts, all of us appreciate it

Alan and Bubba,

First of all I am not a "NO BROOKHAVEN" person.  I do however, now that the city exists, feel it adds no value as do a majority of people in the city. I actually voted for the city.  But thanks for the arrogance. We have a police department and very questionable leadership.  Thats about it. So congrats to us.

As far as wasting tax dollars, I will explain it to you.  The city has very limited resources and funds because of not only the way it was set up in regards to taxation but also in regards to staff that it can afford in correlation with the taxation.  The code enforcement that we have does not need to be taking hours of their day to read ridiculous claims on the internet, let alone spend countless hours to follow up and make on site visits to appease uninformed residents.   But in the end they will do this to satisfy the dumb masses of people who are ignorant to code and building ordinances.  Look on SCF and you will see a ton of things are not worthy of the time it takes to write them.  From this post that has gone on for months or several others where true violations dont exists.  If people are going to complain they need to be educated in the law and not expect the city to chase down every ignorant claim by tax people who hate new growth in District 1.  Which is exactly what this (being the 3 post) and countless others are.  

So when the city can't keep up with worthless claims they hire new people to do it.  This increases the cost of the city to run day to day operations.  We have new salaries, new cars, new office space, etc.  Now you may think that you are "paying for this" but what you are actually doing is creating the need for more city income which it will get from the rest of us who aren't complaining about vans in a driveway.

As far as outsourcing:  the cities code enforcement is not outsourced and its run by city employees.  This is a perfect example of how uninformed people have no business on this site. 

There may be a violation here, maybe.  But hounding the city on 3 separate posts is a ridiculous waste of everyones time and is going to cost us all more in the future.  They are looking into it and if there is a violation it will take time to runs its course and to get the proper paperwork, permits, and variance in order.  And I think after the millions spent on the pink pony lawsuit and stardust we could use a little more of the funds to stay around instead of spending it on things with more importance.

Brookhaven City Manager's office I think part of the problem is that a response has never been provided.  The original post pointed out that it appeared the home was violating the 35% rule and posted the following: 
"Additionally, PAVING of the front yard is limited to a maximum of 35 percent. A front yard is defined by the Zoning Ordinance as the "area extending across the total width of a lot between side lot lines and being that area between the street right-of-way lines and that line or lines established by the front wall or walls of the principal structure projected to intersect the side lot lines."    

So why are the same questions being submitted?   Wasn't a determination as to the 35% already made?      And It seems odd that the sign is not a violation.  

Or should someone contact the code enforcement line directly?

@ Eric - I'm with you. I believe the determination as to the 35% was already made in the prior service request ID 1076647, but this reporter had follow up questions regarding what specific materials are classified as paving material (which would count towards the 35%). 

Although Code Compliance mentioned pea gravel or any gravel/stone/paver material counts towards the 35% in the prior service request -- the reporter wanted to confirm whether actual cement counts towards the 35%. I get the impression that is the major overall concern -- that there is too much cement material covering the front. 

The other issue at hand is what appears may be new developments regarding the potential operation of a commercial business in a residential area. I'd like to have Code Compliance take a second look, since the last site visit was in June, to investigate further to see if the situation has changed. I am thinking the sign might not have been up at the time of the original site visit. I believe this would have been an indicator of the potential business activities that may be taking place there.

We'll look out for an update from Code Compliance on these issues. Thanks to everyone!
commenter_name: City of Brookhaven City Manager's Office

I would also like to see the City enforce laws for our parks.  This park has truly become a "dog park".  Other parks do not seem to have this problem.  I hesitate to take  children to this park because of this issue.  Dog owners--follow the law and be respectful of your neighbors!

I don't have a problem if it's a dog park or not, but it's the city's decision.....not a bunch of residents that just decide they are going to do what they want to do.

I love dogs and have a dog myself. However, I would never allow my little guy to run buck wild at this park unless there is a proper fenced off dog park area. Plus, at this point, I can't even take my dog there on a leash for a lawful outing because of all the lawbreaking dogs that race up and challenge my dog to play. My guy is at a distinct disadvantage in this scenario because we is on a leash. My only recourse is to stay away from the park. We go out to Gwinnett County that has a beautiful facility with segregated play areas (small dog and large dog fenced, well maintained areas) and our money. I really wish Brookhaven could get it together.

The suggestion that the city just declare Brookhaven Park a dog park since people are using it that way already simply rewards the lawbreakers. NOT COOL,

I'd prefer to see some fenced off areas for dogs as well. It's fine to have a dog park section within the park but since the green space in the park is quite large I'd like to see other non-dog related uses for it.

I dont mind a section of the part being a dog park, Its nice for the dogs to be unleashed and have an open space to run around in, but it should be separated from the rest of the park where kids can play or families can have picnics without the concern of a dog running up to them. Its a really large area so I'm sure it can be split up so everyone can enjoy the park equally.

It's a shame I live a block away from this park and cannot take my two year-old because of the considerable number of off-leash dogs.  Brookhaven should either enforce the existing leash laws or deisgnate a fenced-off portion as a dog park.

Clarification for Kay Wolfe and all Brookhaven residents regarding city management and ownership of the parks...

As discussed last night at the city council meeting, the parks were supposed to have been purchased, and title transferred from DeKalb long ago.  However, the day before the new city took over the management of the parks last fall, DeKalb signed a long term lease with the group that leases the facility at Brookhaven Park.  Also, DeKalb did not authorize an Environmental study to be performed as required under state law, before a park property can be purchased or transferred.

Once DeKalb ultimately released authorization late in the fall, the environmental studies were performed.  It was discovered that 3 of the parks have possible environmental contamination, making it illegal for the park property to be transferred until the contamination is remediated.  The city wanted to purchase the parks with no contamination and with no long term lease agreements that prevent the city from managing, improving and owning the park property.  However, DeKalb decided to not transfer any parks unless all parks are transferred.

As a result, the city still doesn’t own the parks and can only merely cut the grass and perform other negligible management activities at this time.  Last night it was reported that after performing more extensive environmental work, only 1 of the parks has contamination that might present a hazard to people utilizing the park.  As a result, the city authorized the city attorney and manager to attempt to purchase all the parks, except the one prohibited by the lease agreement, and for the other park with the contamination to parcel out the area with the contamination until it the contamination is remediated.  However, if DeKalb still wants to make the transfer contingent upon the ability to transfer all park properties, the transfer will not take place for some time.

Until title transfer occurs, the city will not own the parks, will not have the ability to improve them except for cutting grass and only negligible management activities.

I am tired of trying to avoid the dogs that run loose at this park. My little dog is on a leash, but we are soon surrounded by eight huge, excited dogs. It is frightening. Punish the law breakers by making them erect a fence around an area that is just for loose dogs. Then the rest of us can enjoy the park, have a picnic, take a nap in the sun, or even dare to bring small children to this park. Until then, I will go to Skyland Park and walk in peace.

Jeff, during the past year and a half our city manager has continually set dates for park purchase completion that have not been met.  The bottom line is that a seasoned, experienced city manager would have known the details of acquiring our parks and would have taken the bull by the horns and efficiently resolved our parks purchase issue.  Continuing to blame DeKalb is simply getting old.  As someone that has worked so hard over the past two years prior to city incorporation I would think you would demand more from our city council and the high priced city manager they continue to support with her deficient job production for our city.

comment_text: So who is charged with rule enforcement in the park, the city or county police?  Who do we contact to hand out citations to owners whose dogs run off leash?
Unfortunately Betty, while there might be someone that has the ability to write citations, the likelihood of it actually occurring is zero.

Thanks Rick for your comment.  Based on my experience and first hand knowledge, I don't think anyone, anywhere, could have accomplished this any faster.  One of the primary reasons I worked so hard for 2 years to create the new city, is the dysfunction and corruption of DeKalb.  Rather than "do the right thing" and serve constituents, many county employees and some officials prefer to go out of their way (in this case for what they perceive as retribution) to not "do the right thing" and serve constituesnts.  

As a result, it is not a surprise when DeKalb refuses to transfer the parks.  Rather than clean up their own house, some people prefer to continue to attempt to bring their dysfuction into our back yard.  An option would be to file suit, but that could possibly only delay the process.  The mayor and council told Marie and legal counsel Tuesday to go back to DeKalb and demand transfer of the parks immediately, with the exception of the parts of Brookhaven Park and Lynwood Park that cannot be transferred at this time because of the lease and environmental contamination.  We will see how they respond.

Jeff I appreciate your first hand experience with this issue.  You may be too close to the issue, city leaders and management to interpret the history of this issue and how it should actually have been handled by our city representatives.  Yes, in the past ten years DeKalb leadership has gained a reputation for being dysfunctional and corrupt, but in some regards Brookhaven leadership, in its short history, is earning a similar reputation.

Maybe Brookhaven leadership should have used legal action against DeKalb; they seem to excel in being known as the most litigious municipality in the area.  Do you really think continuing to throw stones at DeKalb is a positive contribution to the future of our region of DeKalb County?  I don’t.  What governing body wants to join hands in a future regional governmental program with such a fault finding litigious city governed by vitriolic leaders and leading citizens?

Just for the record, as a Brookhaven resident I deal with DeKalb regularly in several departments professionally and privately as I have always and I find the vast majority of DeKalb employees to be polite and efficient.  This is in spite of their knowing that I am a Brookhaven resident.  I am sorry your business with DeKalb is not as positive.

comment_text:
I have seen Dekalb County Police issue citations at Brook Run Park for off-leash dogs, and there's even an off leash dog park there! What is wrong with people?
I have also seen Cobb County Police issue citations for off leash dogs at the Chattahoochee River Park. So why not in Brookhaven!  We have a very capable police force. Children are put in danger. This is obviously a safety issue, and the citations can generate money for the city! My dog is always on a leash, and is very protective of me when another dog approaches. Will I be held accountable if my dog tears an off-leash dog's ear off or opens a jugular vein with his very sharp teeth?

Yes you will be held accountable. It is your responsibility to make sure your dog does not attack people or other animals. If you cannot control your dog, it should not be allowed in public. You will most likely be financially and legally liable for any injuries and/or damages your dog inflicts. If your dog is then legally determined to be a viscous animal, the authorities will probably be forced to put the animal to sleep.

This one issue where dog lovers and dogophobics can work together.  Lets all lobby for a portion of Brookhaven Park be fenced off and designated an off-leash dog area.   The park is big enough.
No reason for any group of citizens to have their enjoyment of the park curtailed simply to satisfy the wishes of other groups who want to use the park in different ways.   There is enough park there for everybody.  This is one "problem" that can easily be solved with a sturdy fence.
I doubt  Robert Frost had dog playgrounds in mind when he wrote "Good fences make good neighbors,"  but hey ....... its an adage to keep in mind.
David George
Sylvan Circle
There is plenty of park for everyone to enjoy.

There is plenty of park for everyone but if off-leash dogs are free to approach both children and on-leash dogs through the entirety of the park, that's a problem.  Why can't people 1) respect the existing leash laws of the park, 2) take their dogs to sanctioned dog parks, and 3) work to get a section of Brookhaven Park designated a dog park.

Fencing an area of the park and designating it an off-leash area is the best solution.  I'm thinking the meadow beyond the picnic shelter.  Plenty of room in that park for everyone.  And for new uses. (Tennis courts, anybody?       How about a soccer field?.  Or a ball diamond?  AND a dog park.)

I know - if you see someone who has a dog off-leash, approach them as ask for them to put their dog on a leash so you can play in the park with your child.  Message boards are great, but when did people stop talking to one another?  Be the solution, not just another voice...

York55, I've tried nicely asking people to put their dogs on leashes and gotten some not so nice words thrown back at me in return.  My solution has been to avoid using the park I live two blocks from.

Give it a rest, people.   By now everybody is aware that there needs to be a fenced area where dogs can run off-leash without bothering anybody.  Somebody needs to push this issue, even if it means dog owners chipping in to pay for the darn fence  (perhaps a necessity, since the City apparently doesn't feel it can claim ownership of this particular park..)   There ought to be tax money available to build a fence, but the city has opted to spend on other things like a tourism department  and cherry trees.   I was prepared to take up the cause myself, but we are leaving the neighborhood very soon,  so no sense starting something I won't the around to follow through on.   
   David (Pick Up Your Poop) George.

I'd actually hope that the city can just convert the whole park to a dog park instead of some small fenced in area like Brook Run or Piedmont in which too many dogs are crowded together resulting in many fights and a lot of dog poop on the ground.  I used to go to Brook Run but stopped after one very scary time where I was approached by a bull mastiff and all of his buddies as I was leaving with my dog on leash.  I also grew tired of scraping the poop off my shoes after every visit.  This has been my experience with most dog parks - the area is too small and I think it contributes to people being lazy and either not watching their dogs closely or not picking up after them because "it's a dog park". We have been going to the Brookhaven Park with our dog for 7 years.  Back when we started going, the park was not safe to walk in alone as there were often homeless, drunk or drugged people hanging out as the park is close to Marta and set back from the street.  I think this is what allowed the "dog people" to take over as no one else used this park, however this also really helped clean up the park and it no longer seems like an unsafe place.  I would never have ventured over there with my 2 year old before the dogs took over.  It was too scary and there really isn't any playground equipment. 

I also wanted to point out that I actually think this park is a "gem" and closing it down or segregating off a small portion for dogs would be a detriment to the city. We know so many people that have moved to Brookhaven because of this park and we ourselves have mentioned that we wouldn't leave Brookhaven because of this park.  We also know many people that drive from other areas to use the park and then shop at City Dog Market, gas stations, grocery stores, etc. It's also become a community where we have seen multiple couples meet and marry, people make best friends or simply just get some time to play frisbee with their dog after a long day.  

We have a very active dog who unfortunately is not fulfilled with an on leash walk.  I wish he was because it would make our lives so much easier, but we adopted him and we need to take care of him and his needs. As a dog owner, I know I am not in the minority in Brookhaven where it seems like almost everyone owns a dog and everyone enjoys spending time with their dog. I really hope the city considers both sides of this issue.

comment_text: I cannot believe that it is taking so long for something to be done about this.  All they need to do is extend the green light by approximately 8-10 seconds from Clifton Road turning onto Briarcliff Road. Doing this will alleviate the back-up that now exists on Clifton Road.

I guess they are never going to get around to changing the length of the green light in the morning at this intersection.  It's been almost a year that this has been on this board and nothing has happened.  All they need to do is extend the length of the green light from Clifton Road turning onto Briarcliff by about 10 seconds in the morning between 7am - 9am.  When I use this intersection in the afternoons the length of the green light is perfect - why can they not keep it like that for the morning commute too?
Can you please have this problem fixed.  Trying to turn left onto Briarcliff Road from Clifton Road is ridiculous.  It takes three red light cycles!

Well, now they have put in a turn lane but they also need to make the center lane an either "go straight or turn left lane".  At the moment the center lane has a "go straight" arrow on it that goes into a gas station.  Please make that center lane an option to either go straight or turn left - this would solve all the problems at that intersection with cars backing up.  Thanks!

Okay, so there have been modifications to the intersection but now can you PLEASE make the middle lane going from Clifton onto Briarcliff a left turn option lane too.  This will REALLY help keep the traffic moving.

Thanks!

You guys have created another real problem now.  You changed lanes turning from Clifton onto Briarcliff but the lane turns left needs a passing arrow.  By the time all the cars are coming out of the QuikTrip and going straight onto Clifton the cars from Clifton turning left onto Briarcliff cannot go because the light has already turned red.  It's dangerous!  I see numerous cars going through the red light as that is the only opportunity to make that turn.

As a concerned citizen who has noticed this man's unfortunate situation, why don't you help him?  There are so many things you can do besides report him to the City.  I am really worried about the idea that we are planning on moving to Brookhaven now that I see the comments, complaints and overall tattle-tale attitude from the people who actually live in Brookhaven.  Clearly, Brookhaven is filled with many people who have nothing better to do with their lives than complain to others to "fix" anything they consider to be uncomfortable.  Anonymous reporter, Two Lane and all of the other unidentified Brookhaven residents on this site, perhaps you could try to "do" something positive and actually speak to the people who are your neighbors.  You may actually find that your problem is resolved in a more friendly and efficient manner and possibly make a new friend in the process.

Absolutely!! I marvel at how those people think that they are the only ones that have somewhere to be after work. And that where they are going is so much more important than where we are going that they willfully clog up the right turn lane preventing others from going into the office park.

I completely agree and shares this before with some others what are involved in the road. 

I don't think cones are the right answer but once the turn lane actually begins ( not at freeway exit ). The plastic dividers that we see to divide lanes throughout the area are what is needed. They mount to the pavement with a base and they should be added at the office park and the second perimeter summit street. 

I too agree I get so annoyed by people doing this again and again which just causes more gridlock. 

Granted ashford dunwoody and Johnson ferry by the gas station could use some is the same dividers. 

Now if I had my magical wand , dunwoody would add the same to AD at the 285 entrance for those that clog up cutting people off with the one lane that enters on the best big side. ( yes I know this is Brookhaven )

This drives me crazy everytime I drive up this hill from 285 and in front of Cambridge square. I make every opportunity to avoid Cambridge Square after 4PM. I agree the same dividers should be installed at both these locations!!
I agree with installing break away poles or bumpers to force people to turn only in the turn lanes. I work afternoons (2nd Shift) and this area is filled with drivers in a hurry not obeying the laws.

Thank you for reporting issue #1039549. Midtown Alliance is a non-profit organization working to improve the Midtown Community.   While basic infrastructure repair and maintenance remain the responsibility of the City of Atlanta, our full-time staff works to enhance these services in the district.  To this end, we address outstanding issues as quickly as we can and as our budget and authority allow.  For those issues that lie outside of our purview, we will advocate for resolution on your behalf.  Once we have reviewed your report you will receive a message detailing the steps that will be taken to resolve the issue.

This issue was reported by Midtown Alliance staff.  Please note that the Midtown Alliance uses SeeClickFix to track and manage repair issues and, in many cases, will voluntarily address these issues to supplement City services.  In other cases, we will coordinate with the City to accomplish these repairs.

completed

I just got home from the park - this issue was prematurely closed - not only are the bathrooms still locked, they have a sign duct-taped to both of the doors.

Please leave this issue open until the bathrooms are open - it needs to go to the top of the list.

Families use this park regularly as well as the neighborhood delivery drivers.
We will forward to the Parks Maintenance Supervisor.  At the time the initial issue was closed, the bathrooms were unlocked and being serviced daily.

Per Park Maintenance:

They are locked due to a major water line break.  We will have to replace a section of the line before they can be reopened.  Plumbers have come our, assessed the damage and will schedule the repair as soon as possible.

Thanks Richard, hopefully they will understand this does not need to drag out for too long.  A fellow that was there more than three weeks ago said there was a line break.  As far as them being unlocked and serviced daily when the issue was closed on 4/10 - sounds like a communication breakdown - they have been closed for quite some time possibly due to the line break.  However, good to know a repair is being scheduled.  To us daily users of the park, they are an important fixture.

Just got home from the park and there was a fire at one of the pavillions near the bathrooms - no water at the spitgots to put it out - this problem of no water needs to be addressed sooner than later.  
Thanks
Brookhaven Department of Public Works assigned this issue to Brookhaven Department of Parks and Recreation
Brookhaven Department of Public Works assigned this issue to Brookhaven Department of Parks and Recreation

The bathrooms have been repaired however, it appears damage was done to the women's bathroom door because it will no longer close - the door will not fit into its frame.  Was this reported on the workorder or some type of notation made when the work was inspected by the city?
Additional photo of the women's bathroom door
This problem is about to hit the two month mark and the official start of summer is this weekend.  Has the women's bathroom door been repaired so that it will close?  Should I open a new ticket?

Per Parks Maintenance - The water line has been repaired and other than the door issue, the bathrooms should be operational.  They will have someone look at the door issue tomorrow.  Typically, if it is a new issue, it should be opened as a new ticket, but in this case, we will address it under this ticket.

Thanks

Thanks Richard, I'll check it when I'm over there tomorrow.  I do not mind opening a new ticket though.  
Please note  - who signed off on the repair?  Certainally there was QC involved before the bill was paid - someone had to know the door had a problem because they had to go in and out of the bathroom to turn the water on and off, clean it - stock it etc..  Believe me - this is not a situation where the door is hard to shut - the door has been knocked off its kilter between the time it was locked for repairs and unlocked when the repair was finished. It actually slams into the jamb, it can't even be forced shut  - not something that is easy to miss and it concerns me that no one caught it.
The bathroom door is fixed - thanks!
If we have a parks department you would think they would be on top of these issues without waiting for citizens to complain.

Rick - until we hire actual employees and get away from contracting - it will never work. While the contract guys that I have met down there are nice, they are from another town and do not have a stake in the future of the park - it is a job to them until the contract runs out. I read something that you might want to try. Since it's Sunday it may be a while before the city can respond. 

Cleaning Wet Paint Spills

It is much easier to clean up fresh, wet paint. Speed is the key here. As soon as you spill paint on concrete, act immediately. Whether it is water- or oil-based, first absorb as much as possible. If you're outside, use dirt. Cat litter, sand and potting soil work as well. If it's just a few drips, quickly rubbing a little dirt into it may be all that is needed. For larger spills, sweep the absorbent material and paint mix up, and use the appropriate solvent to clean the area. Using a hose and a stiff bristled brush is effective for water-based paint.

comment_text: Yes! and during heavy rain nearly the whole Brookhaven Walk NE street is a river. A guests car has been flooded just by standing in the street during a heavy rain. If those storm drains ever back up this whole neighborhood is going have a serious problem.
City of Brookhaven has logged this concern. We will have an update shortly.

As a resident of Tallulah, I can confirm that this happens.  Too late now, but it sure would've been nice if the 'authorities' had not approved removal of vritually all the trees and other living plant life which prior to the over development of Tallulah, did a respectable job of controlling run-off.  If corrective measures need to be taken that are going to cost the City (and subsequently its taxpayers) money, I'd like to see you pursue the developers who simply had to see this coming.  I feel very bad for the folks downstream.  Not only is there water, but also a fair amount of soil/mud that runs off, too.

Just wanted to add a few pictures to show the issue a little better. These were taken from our driveway at 1004 Brookhaven Walk NE. You can see how the street turns into a semi river during rain and how the storm drain on our side of the street doesn't even seem to be taking all of the water (even though this was not a very heavy downpour)(see red circle in picture) this worries me for the homes further down Brookhaven Walk, in case of a very significant rainfall for a lengthy period of time. The main issue here has been present for a while and it is the fact that during a storm you can follow the water flow from the top of Osborne (by Peachtree), it flows down Osborne on the right hand side of the road and then exactly by the upper Brookhaven Walk entrance it crosses over and rushes down our street. The only solutions I can think of would be to have a drain put in that stretches across our street as Pelly Circle NE has it (one neighborhood over) or to somehow change the way Osborne Road's bend makes the water flow down here.
another picture

Yes.  As a homeowner on Brookhaven Walk,I totally agree that this is a severe problem that needs to be corrected.  The amount of water is way above any normal runoff.  It was clearly not engineered properly.  In addition to the problem for surrounding homeowners, it is a dangerous traffic hazard for all traffic on Osborne Road during heavy rains and surely is not within normal safety standards/code.   Thank you for your conscientious attention to this prolonged problem.
The flooding is extreme and should be flowing into the sewer drain. We will take a look at your street to determine what exactly is the problem.

Yes, this is a serious issue for Brookhaven Walk.  I am at 1010 Brookhaven Walk and we are one house after the storm drain.  One would assume that the run off would not be that bad beyond the drain, but the amount and speed of water coming down Brookhaven Walk is too much for any drain to handle.  During moderate rain, the entire street looks like the pictures posted above by Brad.

comment_text: I have reported this issue several times before.  Traffic north and south on Ashford Dunwoody can mostly be very light, but the lights remain green for them.  Please check this--today at 4p (and I make this trip mostly every day at this time) I counted 14 cars lined up on West Nancy Creek headed east, and 8 cars on West Nancy Creek headed west.  Thanks!
This is a residential road - 25 mph speed limit and no yellow line in the middle of the road. There shouldn't be so much stationary traffic on a daily basis.

Part of the problem is people constantly doing illegal U turns out the island by New Generations. I estimate 2 out of 3 cars leaaving St Josephs do this. Either the plice need to sit there and give tickets or they need to put up a barrier.

In afternoon rush hour, the traffic still is backed up about a mile on West Nancy Creek which is a residential road. It also backs up on the east side approaching the intersection of Ashford-Dunwoody and West Nancy Creek. This drives more traffic onto side roads like Parkcrest and Brenton.

This problem has become unbearable especially around 4p on week-days with traffic backing up on W. Nancy Creek at Ashford Dunwoody.  Friday, coming from Murphey Candler Park, it took me 20 minutes to get to the Y because I had to sit through several light cycles.  All times of the day the light stays green for north/south bound Ashford Dunwoody traffic (even when there are no/few cars) and stays red an inordinate amount of time for cars travelling east/west on W. Nancy Creek.  Brookhaven, please check the timing of these lights.  The lights at Ashford Dunwoody/Harts Mill/Marist School seem to have been adjusted for smoother traffic flow there.

We are often stuck here for 5-6 cycles before getting through going east to west across Ashford Dunwoody. Often only 1-2 cars can make it at a time since most westbound traffic is turning left and there are so many cars coming from the opposite direction. A designated left turn signal might be helpful.
I still don't see any improvement at this intersection. Cars wait for multiple light changes before they can cross the intersection.

It seems like a turn signal for westbound drivers on West Nancy Creek would be very helpful.  And a traffic study of the intersection would give some data as to how best time the light.  The Brookhaven mayor grew up near this intersection, seems like he would know how bad it gets.
I agree, a traffic study needs to be completed.  I live 1/2 mile down on W. Nancy Creek Drive and can't get into or out of my driveway due to traffic.

Okay, we as regular drivers of W. Nancy Creek / Ashford Dunwoody, all seem to agree that the timing of the lights at this intersection need some monitoring / adjustments.  Could we now hear from the City of Brookhaven?  Sure would appreciate knowing that our voices are being heard and that some fixes are being considered!  JG

They don't need to do a Study, they just need to go out one afternoon at 4 at look for themselves and then adjust the timing so there is more time for West Nancy Creek Traffic.  

Where is the Brookhaven response/update?
Hello. We are aware of the timing adjustments needed perhaps. Thank you for your concern and a follow up will be posted accordingly.
Thanks, Brookhaven, for promptly responding!  We look forward to any adjustments / improvements that can be made at this intersection.  JG
Promptly?  looks like its been open since August.
Hello, I live on West Nancy Creek and I hope something can be done to fix the light system, the backup along the street is a regular event and extremely frustrating.
The light stays red too long on West Nancy Creek - It's about 2 1/2 to 3 minutes long. Traffic is backed up over 1 mile at evening rush hour. This is too much for a residential road.

I still don't see any improvement in the traffic that backs up on W Nancy Creek on both sides of Ashford-Dunwoody. (aside from this being a holiday week)  On this Thanksgiving weekend, I'm thankful that I no longer work in Vinings so I'm not trapped in this nightmare heading eastbound on W Nancy Creek. At least, going westbound, I can cut through on Brenton and head north to turn around on Chaucer, so I can go south on AshDun and turn on Parkcrest to get to W Nancy Creek.

I think there have been sufficient comments on this issue from people who regularly sit at this light.  Could we please hear from City of Brookhaven?  The light at Harts Mill/Ashford Dunwoody seems to be adjusted nicely to accommodate cars entering and exiting Marist at their peak hours.  Does that intersection's light(s) timing have anything to do with not being able to adjust the W. Nancy Creek/Ashford Dunwoody lights?  Please let us know you are reading these posts and whether or not adjustments can be made.  Thanks!  JG
This is a HUGE problem -- in order to accommodate a private school, we cannot get out of our neighborhoods in the late afternoon.  City of Brookhaven, why are you not responding to this?
I seem to remember reading somewhere that PTOP was in charge of the timing of these lights.

This signal is being timed as part of the PTOP program.  The consultant doing the timing work for PTOP has looked at this intersection and there is not much from a timing issue that they can do to help W Nancy Creek.  The issue is the volume of traffic on Ashford Dunwoody.  Giving more time to W Nancy will just back up A-D more which wont help relieve W Nancy.  We are going to begin our Comprehensive Transportation Plan in January and the Ashford Dunwoody/Johnson Ferry Corridor and this intersection will be looked at closely for what near term and long term improvements can be made.

With all due respect to your response, it does not ring true with someone who travels W Nancy Creek several times daily.  Even at peak afternoon/evening traffic hours, I see the traffic flowing smoothly (and at times, very few cars) on Ashford Dunwoody with an inordinate number of cars backed up half a mile eastbound and westbound on W Nancy Creek.  I still wonder if the timing of this light is somehow connected to the sophisticated light timings at Harts Mill/Ashford Dunwoody/Marist School.  That light has designated left turn arrows for all directions of traffic, including entering and exiting turn lights to and from the school.  I certainly don't have the answer, but saying "there is not much from a timing issue that can be done" just is not acceptable.  I have no idea who or what "PTOP" is.

I second JG's comments.  The "consultant" probably does a fly by at morning or evening rush hour when Ashford Dunwoody is congested.  This has become a huge problem over the past 12 months and was not an issue on a regular basis prior to that.  I get the impression that the people who want to widen Ashford Dunwoody have no incentive to fix this or look into it because it helps their cause.  And widening Ashford Dunwoody will just bring in more traffic.  Unless the current City of Brookhaven officials improve their responsiveness on issues like this, they will become the former City of Brookhaven officials.

@Richard Meehan.   With all due respect the consultant is wrong.    There is a very long timing cycle between greens for West Nancy Creek Traffic at Ashford Dunwoody.   And the Ashford Dunwoody traffic does not get backed up at this light. Eric - regarding my observations of Ashford Dunwoody flow in the PM, from what I have seen, all of the intersections, including W Nancy Creek and Harts MIll, backup traffic to some degree.  How much each intersection does, and how much the backup from one intersection "bleeds": into the one preceding it depends on the volume on Ashford Dunwoody in a particular day.  This volume can vary significantly based on several factors including is there soccer at the YMCA that afternoon, does Marist have a special event/afternoon sports activity, how bad in the congestion on I-285.  This last one probably has the biggest impact.  On days I-285 is heavily congested, more vehicles will divert to Ashford Dunwoody.  On those days, I would expect that there is also higher "cut through" traffic from Johnson Ferry on W Nancy which makes that backup worse as well.  One of the things the PTOP program is looking at in the coming year is the possibility of implementing "Traffic Responsive" or "Traffic Adaptive" timing.  Without getting to much into the technical details here, these systems basically will use a computer algorithm to dynamically adjust the signal timings based on traffic volumes on a given day.  Right now, the signal timing is based on "Time of Day" plans that were developed and adjusted using "average" volumes for a particular time period.  Under this system, the signal will call the same timing plan at the same time everyday, regardless of the volumes on that particular day.  To get to the ability to use either Traffic Responsive or Traffic Adaptive, there will need to be an upgrade of the signal equipment, specifically the computers, detectors, and the communications between signals.  We have applied for a grant to the Atlanta Regional Commission for the funding to do these upgrades and we should here about that soon after the New Year.

JG - regarding the Marist/Harts Mill light, as you mentioned, that signal does have Left Turn arrows and Left Turn lanes for the side roads.  Besides the differences in volumes from those roads from W Nancy Creek, that is the biggest reason why that signal operates "more smoothly" for the drivers on Harts Mill and Marist.  At W Nancy Creek, one car attempting to turn left on Ashford Dunwoody can block all other cars from going through the intersection.  So even if there is green time for say 15-20 cars on a particular cycle, if the first or second car is turning left and has to wait for opposing traffic, you may only have 3 or 4 cars get through on that cycle which will further back up traffic on W Nancy.  Since there are no Left Turn Lanes on W Nancy Creek, adding Left Turn Arrows for W Nancy will not improve the flow on that road.  With turn arrows and no turn lanes, if the first car or 2 is going straight or right, they will block the left turners from proceeding on the arrow resulting in the same problem.  The standards that the City must follow require that for a turn arrow phase to be installed, there must be a dedicated turn lane.  

Adding left (and/or right) turn lanes on the W Nancy Creek at this intersection and subsequently adding the appropriate turn arrows if needed is ONE possible solution to this intersection that will be looked at. But as with any other solution, it will need to be studied and fully vetted with the community, through both the CTP process and any subsequent improvement plan development before it is implemented.

Finally, we are aware of and we do read all the comments posted and we are trying to respond to them as quickly as we can,  However, depending on our schedule here and what other issues we are dealing with, it can occasionally take us some time to post a formal response to questions.  We are very aware of the issue here and very much want to work with the community to develop a workable solution.

Thanks

If we make improvements to the intersection at W Nancy/Ashford Dunwoody whether adding turn lanes or adjusting timing, that is just going to encourage more cars from Johnson Ferry to cut through. We continue to work to optimize the timing of this intersection, but in the afternoon it is already saturated on both roads. To add time to one direction takes it away from the other and backs up traffic further.  Both Old Johnson Ferry and West Nancy Creek have traffic calming measures in place to reduce speeding and discourage cut trough’s and while the speeding is not the issue, the cut through traffic is not being discouraged from using that route.

I am continuing to work on addressing this issue, working with PCID and Sandy Springs on the overall traffic situation, and including working contacting St Joes to discuss their signage and also talking to their employees about the use of that drive/roundabout on Old Johnson Ferry.  We are also started to work on our Comprehensive Transportation Plan.  The Ashford Dunwoody Corridor, including W Nancy Creek Dr and the cut through traffic issue in this area have been identified as problem areas that need to be addressed in our plan.  This plan will guide and set priorities for transportation improvements citywide.  I encourage you to participate in the process by contacting a steering committee member (found on the CTP page on the city website: http://brookhavenga.gov/city-government/boards-commissions/steering-committees , attending the Steering Committee and Public meetings to provide input, submit comments to the Transportation Email, and participate in surveys and other public outreach that the City and their Consultant will be doing throughout this process.  Our schedule is to have this plan completed by the end of July for presentation to the City Council in August.  

Thanks

Trevor L.,  The city does have a program to add speed humps to a residential street under our Traffic Calming Program .  This process does require a petition from the neighborhood and a speed/traffic study.  If you email me at my city email address, I can send you the initial petition forms and detail information on the process so you can get started.

Sandy Springs PW got back with me this week.  They have acknowledged that the No U-turn sign is missing and they have a work order in place to replace the sign with a new one.  With the NO U turn sign in place, COSS PD will be able to enforce and write citations.

Regarding the roundabout sign, that is a standard sign for roundabouts required by the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) the standards we (and Sandy Springs) must follow.  It is a regulatory sign indicating to a motorist to circle to the right instead of cutting the wrong way to the left.  Placement of that sign does not mean that a U-turn is permitted.

As for the changes to the curb, there records indicate that the curb was always like it is now and that the office development on the southeast corner of Old Johnson Ferry and Johnson Ferry and their drive on Old JF was there before the roundabout was built.  If their information is incorrect, i would contact Sandy Springs PW directly.  Please note that based on the dates provided above, Sandy Springs either was not a city yet or was just starting themselves, and many of the staff currently there were not there back in 2006-07

I will continue to work with Sandy Springs and PCID to contact St Josephs about clarifying signage and to inform their employees to not make illegal u-turns at the roundabout.

We will also continue to address this issue as part of the CTP process.  The CTP looks at all of the traffic and transportation issues in the city.  From that process, a plan is developed identifying the potential projects, the general scope of those projects, budget estimates, and, based on anticipated funding, a prioritization and timeline for implementing any projects.  While it does need to address long term (20 year) horizon, it will also look at the short term and determine what improvements will be made in the next 5-10 years.  This is a citizen driven process and citizen input into what needs to be done and what is important to you is a large piece of determining the plan and the final project list.  The master schedule for the CTP and the other plans underway (Land Use, Parks, Buford Hwy) is posted on the city website: http://brookhavenga.gov/city-government/boards-commissions/steering-commitees/transportation-

our next CTP meeting is the open house on May 28th at 6-8 PM at Briarwood Park Recreation Center.

Thanks

Consider:
St. Josephs is now part of Emory - - Emory St. Josephs.  Emory may not honor any agreements with St. Josephs, depending on how they were written (does the agreement survive the acquisition?).
Emory St.Josephs and the hundreds of medical practices in that complex are a major taxpayers for Sandy Springs.  This fact is likely behind the changes made to the traffic circle to allow U-turns.  This fact will likely keep Sandy Springs from taking action which will hurt the hospital complex.

I have followed up with Brad Edwards at Sandy Springs again today and he was not aware that the no U-turn sign had not been installed yet.  He was going to follow up and see what was the delay and get the sign installation expedited,

Regarding the signal at Ashford Dunwoody/West Nancy Creek, we have had our consultant look at the option of "split" phasing the signal for West Nancy Creek which is what was suggested above.  According to them, split phasing would not improve the traffic situation on W Nancy creek and could actually make it worse as will reduce the overall green time available.  Right now, W Nancy is getting about 49 seconds of green time per cycle (this is an increase of what it was when we started looking at this issue).  When you split phase, this green time would be split between the two approaches and will require additional yellow and all red time which will effectively reduce the overall green time.

We are continuing to look at this issue a work to develop options to help improve the traffic situation.  In discussion with our Police Chief and City Manager, we are going to add "No Through Traffic" signs on Old Johnson Ferry at the City Limits.  While these signs are not enforceable, they may help to let drivers know they are not supposed to cut through.

We are also in the process of making operation improvements to the intersection of Johnson Ferry and Ashford Dunwoody which will reduce the Southbound backup on both these roads.  While not removing all of the cut through traffic, this should help reduce it.  We expect this work, which will consist of restripping and signal improvements, is expected to start this summer and be completed in early fall.

Thanks

We are not doing any widening, just removing the islands near the Valero and restriping both AD and JF Southbound so that there are two lanes on each entering the area between the Valero and Donaldson where there are already two lanes SB. It will attract more cars if it relieves congestion since people will use it to the point of the back up making other routes more attractive.   I'm not saying I object to the project, just saying what anyone whose been here since 285 was first opened and 400 first opened already know. 

As to being shown to the public are speaking of that photo shopped picture of the intersection?  That's not showing it to the public and its not soliciting input.     There is much that can be done with the striping and the point of a smaller city is to facilitate community input.   That's not happening here. 

Yes its understood the edge of pavement is not being moved just the island and the two Oak Trees in the Island are being removed and re striping in the intersection.   But the impacts are larger since it will increase the amount and speed of traffic.   Again I'm not saying I oppose it.  Just wish there was some community involvement in the design of the project. 

But back to West Nancy and Ashford Dunwoody.  We need a light with an arrow even if there is no turn lane it will help immensely.   Getting only a couple westbound cars through a cycle is not a good thing.   You can cut the amount of time westbound traffic has green by 75%, if there is an arrow it will help immensely.   As to Eastbound get the no U-turn sign installed and some enforcement of it that will help.
It's up!!

First, it has taken months and months of threatening, pleading and nagging to get that No U Turn sign reinstalled.  Thank you Richard for contacting Sandy Springs and reminding them from time to time to reinstall this sign.  I hope that someone will let the Sandy Springs police department know that placing an officer in the parking lot of the building shown in Nancy's picture in the late afternoons would likely produce a huge revenue stream until those drivers used to making that U Turn understand that it is really prohibited.

Richard, we'll look forward to the No Through Traffic signs -- and it would be really good if Sandy Springs would restore the striping to reinforce the No U Turn sign at the traffic teardrop.  Also, the "rotary" sign on Old Johnson Ferry needs to be replaced with one that indicates one cannot go all the way around the island -- in other words, it ought to be a horseshoe rather than a circle.

With respect to Eric's most recent post, I absolutely agree that there has been no input sought about whatever the plan is for the Ashford Dunwoody/Johnson Ferry intersection.  There are many aspects of this that would warrant well-publicized open meetings for discussion:  for those northbound through the intersection on Ashford Dunwoody Road, for example, left turns into the Cambridge Shopping Center should be prohibited from 5 pm to 7 pm as should left turns out of the shopping center onto Ashford Dunwoody northbound.  Those wishing to enter or exit the shopping center during those hours should do so via Johnson Ferry.  For those of us who live in this part of Brookhaven, this intersection is probably one of THE most critical traffic issues as most of us go through the intersection more than once a day.

comment_text:
West Nancy and Ashford Dunwoody. We need a light with an arrow even if there is no turn lane it will help immensely. Like at Oak Forest and Ashford Dunwoody, or Savoy and Chamblee Dunwoody eastbound gets its own time with a green arrow and then the east bound gets its own time with a green arrow and straight.    

Right now only a couple westbound cars are able to make through the intersection each cycle, that is not a good thing. You can cut the amount of time westbound traffic has green by 75%, if there is a green arrow many more cars will get through the intersection in a fraction of the time.

Has any progress been made on getting a new traffic light for this intersection?  This intersection needs to be like the one just up the Street at Ashford Dunwoody and Oak Forrest/Perimeter Summit.  Oak Forrest Drive does not have a turn lane but instead has a left turn signal that goes on with the Green Light.  The Green and light and left arrow then switches over to the other side of Ashford Dunwoody to Perimeter Summit to allow that traffic to move.

I understand how the Consultant came to his conclusion (relayed by Richard M on 6-10) that this "split" timing would not improve any thing because it leads to less total green light time for West Nancy Creek traffic.    

However the Consultant made a mistake I assume because he is not aware of the traffic flows and the fact that traffic depending on the time of day is heavily tilted to eastbound traffic coming from Sandy Springs.    

Split timing could dramatically reduce the westbound West Nancy Creek green light  time dramatically  and still improve the situation dramatically.    As it stands now the encroaching westbound cars trying to squeeze between the non stop eastbound traffic turning right to go south or going straight creates more confusion and also leaves the intersection non functional for westbound West Nancy Creek traffic.   In other words, in the afternoon westbound West Nancy Creek traffic east of Ashford Dunwoody in effect has no Green Light time.   

It works at Oak Forrest which has higher traffic counts so it shouldn't be that big of a leap of faith for Brookhaven to believe it would work at this intertersection. 

We need a light with an arrow and split timing!

Richard:  I agree with Eric on this one.  When I absolutely must go south on Ashford Dunwoody between 5:30 and 6:30 most weeknights, I come close to developing road rage at the never ending stream of eastbound traffic and the truly clueless drivers headed west on Nancy Creek who just sit there like lumps rather than moving out into the intersection.  The other night, it took 3 light cycles before I could get through the intersection.

Even with the no U turn sign up at the Old Johnson Ferry traffic horseshoe, there are plenty of cars coming out of St. Joseph that just ignore it and make the U turn anyway.  It would be helpful to ask that Sandy Springs occasionally put a car in the parking lot of the office building there and issue some tickets -- also, please remind them that they need to restripe that area to reinforce the No U turn message.  Right now we are in what should a bit of a lull in the traffic with vacations and no school traffic.  It can and will get worse.
Issue 1285741 has been marked as a duplicate of this issue.
commenter_name: City of Brookhaven City Manager's Office

comment_text: Just wondering status of this issue.  Traffic continues to back up east and west-bound on W. Nancy Creek at Ashford Dunwoody (especially morning and mid-to-late afternoons).  We have asked repeatedly over the past year+ that adjustment be made to the timing of this light.  Never seems to be any improvement in light timing.  Headed west on W. Nancy Creek, and turning left on Ashford Dunwoody (when the light finally turns green and traffic clears enough to make a left turn there) almost ALWAYS when you then get to Marist / Harts Mill, that light is red for Ashford Dunwoody drivers.  Please give West Nancy Creek drivers a longer (and more frequent green light) !
