comment_text:
As I said before the best and easiest solution is to replace the traffic light with a traffic light with a left hand turn signal the one at the intersection of Oak Forest/Perimeter Summit and Ashford Dunwoody or the one at the intersection of Savoy and Chamblee Dunwoody.    Then you give east bound and westbound Ashford Dunwoody their own green light cycles as is done at the above mentioned intersections.    The total time could be less than the time given now but you would move more cars since you don't have the issue of cars stopping and starting because of the conflicting turn movement situation you have now. 

as seen at Oak Forest you don't need a dedicated turn lane to make that work.

Think about it, if it works just up the street at Oak Forest where they have higher traffic counts why wouldn't it work just down the street at West Nancy.
I think this sounds like a great solution, Eric, and I would hope City of Brookhaven agrees and will strongly consider this option (soon).  City?

This seems to be to completely different topics in this one thread. One is the missing u turn in sandy springs the other being the intersection at AD/ Nancy Creek. With another person noting the u-turn is back how do we ensure that we have issues with more clarity since this one spans to different items. Thanks .

Douglas, true, though both points are related.  The issue started with the need for a timing adjustment or new traffic light with turn signal at Ashford Dunwoody and West Nancy Creek like the one at Perimeter Summit-Oak Forrest and Ashford Dunwoody. 

The problem is that with the amount of traffic coming from Pill Hill its impossible to make a left hand turn from West Nancy Creek on to Ashford Dunwoody if you are coming from Murphey Candler Lake. 

Many later correctly noted that the U-Turn sign was missing.   This seemingly simple task to a great deal of time to resolve.  And the fact that many from the St. Joseph campus were doing a U-Turn here was cited as a problem since the design of the teardrop was to discourage use of Old Johnson Ferry as a cut through by making this U-Turn illegal.    The question is, has the sign stopped this practice?  Is Sandy Springs enforcing it.  

But I suspect even if Sandy Springs does enforce the No-U-Turn the Ashford Dunwoody and West Nancy Creek intersection will still be dysfunctional at Rush Hour.  

Brookhaven earlier had responded that the PCID's consultants had set the timing of the lights to optimize traffic flow [I suspect with an eye towards giving Perimeter Center Commuters the maximum green time].     Though adjusting the light to provide some more green time for West Nancy would not hurt traffic from the PCID since this light is not where traffic is backing up.  

However, even with that, the amount of traffic and the uncertainty of the situtation at rush hour with high volumes of on coming traffic I think dictate use of a signal with a turn signal so that each direction of West Nancy gets there own period of time when the signal is green.   By removing the uncertainty you not only can move more cars in less time but you will also improve safety.

So we have still not gotten a traffic light with a turn signal for this intersection, like the one that appears up the Street at Ashford Dunwoody and Oak Forrest.

Thank you for reporting issue #582945.  After driving through this area, we have determined that there has never been a crosswalk at 4th St/Juniper St with the exception of the crosswalk going across 4th St at this intersection.  In order to properly assist you, we are asking that you please ensure the this location is indeed accurate.  Thank you for keeping Midtown safe and clean.

Thanks for responding-- There was a crosswalk there before Juniper was repaved, but it's probably been a couple years.  If I can find an old picture with the crosswalk, would that help with getting the city to repaint it?
Here's an image I found from the past with the crosswalk.

Again, thank you for bringing this issue to our attention.  There will be an upcoming streetscape project on Juniper St and the painting of the crosswalks at the Juniper St/4th St intersection is being discussed at this time.  We will keep you updated with any pertinent information.  Thank you for keeping Midtown safe and clean.

Susan Rawlins - sarawlins@bellsouth.net

potholes are not in Sandy Springs but in the new city of Brookhaven
these potholes have STILL NOT BEEN REPAIRED!!
The City of Brookhaven will never see this report, because the marker is pointing to a location in Sandy Springs.

Those planters have been there for 5 years, as an attempt to show support to holidays. I do agree they need to be looked at, but not just the flags, overall all of it. This shopping center created a farmers market on Thursdays to bring in people, and all the city can bring them now is grief. I get Dekalb was a big county but a loud enough person (with such clear knowledge of the sections in violation) would have had this addressed. Or contact the leasing company, their number is clearly posted on the for lease spaces. Would potentially the very bright LED lights on the cleaners, which the Kroger one recently did the same create some type of driving hazard as well?  

Corner Pizza added a flag and they could "possibly" be in violation for improper placement? The flag being used for advertising tool, that is completely subjective and I highly suggest you take a look around at places with US Flags. In my book, a car dealership with a GIANT US Flag to draw attention would be doing the same thing. For being someone so patriotic for the flag, leave Corner Pizza alone. 

Brookhaven - If you allow people to report stuff, this website should really require people to at least have an account. It seems cowardly to post sections of code as "anonymous". I hope the city takes that into consideration in requiring that. If not, this website will diminish in value, add credibility. In the time to post this, or research the sections of code, the person could have created account. If they were driving, they should not violate the law of texting (essentially what you are doing) while behind the wheel of an automobile. 

 If the City has the time for someone to go to Corner Pizza and review a potential placement issue, this city currently has too much time on it's hands already.
I tend to agree. I live neaby and pass by this at least weekly. It isn't an eyesore. There are bigger issues to address.

Really, it's across the street, in the shopping center with all of the restaurants, that needs fixing.  What the heck is that ...fountain ... thing that they have there?  And the wagon with the hay?  That whole intersection is an eyesore.
Corner pizza - advertising ?!?! Really ?
No faded flags , on sticks sold on , grass clean .
The wagon mentioned ... Cleaned up - and the shopping center is "crossings" also look at the historical location sign ( graffitied ) - which fits the wagon ...

Corner pizza and planters--- cleaned up, and the planters have been part of the location since built ...
Must have been a code violation then too....
Plenty of room on sidewalk , unless its meant for a car to drive on
Sidewalk - plenty of room - and these type of flags must be a violation and the stores should immediately stop selling them .

How about people read the historical site sign --- the wagon relates . Yes fountain needs to go and the flags in the planters before the restaurants need to go. Those are faded. Did not realize a wagon on a historical "crossing" site is a violation of some type ... Again Brookhaven if this is a priority in first few months of government ...

Better yet --- fix the intersection, signal timing - as reported . I would prefer to see less people gunning it through a light with many senior citizens around. Add in 600 new residents in the apartments and new homes and this area is going to be a nightmare. Though Brookhaven did elect to stop the round about proposed solution that many other cities use to expedite traffic throughout , with signals of course guiding traffic .

I think the entire shopping center is a dilapidated eyesore and our community deserves better from this property owner.  I support a close examination of all potential code violations for the benefit of the community and the tenants.

If the planters and the ridiculous fountain are in the right of way they should be removed. If code requires a permit for planters, flags, fountains, benches and all other assortment of stuff the land owner should be required to get a permit. It is really that simple.  Any other code violations are just that "violations" and they should be treated as such.  The city has a department to address code violations, it is not about having more important things to address.

All good - go welcome to Brookhaven - this is a code guy and he is here to review your premises and advise of all your violations . Again , welcome and a great benefit of the city. Now that we have a city, lets complain about a place around for half a decade - boo hoo. This has probably been around longer then most people complaining being residences . Started about complaints about flags . Maybe we can submit all of our neighborhoods for code compliance review too, no doubt would find something. Maybe people thought this is Phipps mall - or maybe the next and how about we just demand things to a place where restaurants go under as is. These little restaurants will all be there is with the new construction now having no restaurants as part of the plan . 

Regarding code staffing - seriously ? It is a matter of staffing - there no doubt is tons of other places that are violations of a bigger nature . One less code person and study and fix the traffic here - but by the replies I can see how this item is high importance . I suggest we create the flag police , plenty of my neighbors do have them up, our HOA covenants so no but look at the cases , never going to fly legally. 

A flag being used for advertising ... This thread has turned into people demanding a shopping center to be revamped cause we dont like it ... off the mark now a so has the entire point of this site . Goes into how people report the same thing 3 times cause they can't figure it out --- not create a login. Not worth the time for people who have irrational expectations in 6 months of a city.
OK, Douglas, we'll just let you tell us what we should be concerned about.

Yep, the Mesh Corners site is wacky and could use a face lift, yep, some of the things being demanded are completely unreasonable, yep, this forum provides a wonderful opportunity to notify the new "City" of potential hazards and repair issues.  

Unfortunately, even  greater is the opportunity to create a clearinghouse for ill will and animosity between neighbors as is evidenced by this one issue.  The owner has receive harassing phone calls and death threats for her stance on the new city and viewpoints. Really? For being part of the process?  My comments will remain anonymous for similar reasons.   I also believe aesthetic improvements are necessary, there's no love lost on the property,  but are we going to be neighbors that continually use public forums to report each other for minor violations? No, this will be my first and last posting.  I also think this this should be a yes-no vote for prioritization, not a forum, which I'm guilty of. 

Take a look across the street on the boundary of Cambridge Park at the dilapidated fencing, dumping of yard debris on right of way and unsightly brush and trees growing on the right of way and power lines before casting too many stones. (This could apply to the corner of Murphy Candler and Ashford Dunwoody, not my taste in landscaping but better than when it sat barren, vacant and depreciating,  permitting aside) You are my neighbors and friends and I would like to think if ever there were an issue, you would offer a neighbor a carrot before beating him overheard with a stick, and maybe even overlook flaws in favor of more pressing business. "But the place is terrible" yea I hear you, next.

 I could fill a landfill with residential landscaping and trees which overhang and obstruct sidewalks on your streets. I would rather duck my head and bow to a friendly community.
Thank you for reporting this to the City of Brookhaven. We will evaluate the situation and have one of Code Compliance staff get back to you with an answer shortly.

This almost has the appearance of an individual using government to solve their personal vendetta with a commercial property owner.  Violations should certainly be addressed, but future misuse of this system for harassment of the property owner as we have seen in forums over the past year with no basis should be ignored and claimants in violation of civic spirit should be called out by the City of Brookhaven.  This is not what Brookhaven is supposed to be.  Go back to your HOA.
It too hope that some of the crap this owner has placed in the parking lot and along the sidewalk of this shopping center constitute code violations so it can be removed.

This continues to be an issue.  Those of us who ride the bus have taken to blocking the hole with whatever debris we can find. We have used an old traffic cone, tire, and cement block.  While each of these has been removed by the city, at no point have they made an effort to seal the hole.

No the potholes in Wellington Court Apartments have not been fixed, in fact they are getting larger. I went to the leasing office to see if the potholes will be fixed and they looked at me as if they were surprised about the potholes. The sewer project on Roswell Road...I agree.  I live in the area and the neighborhood was assured by the city this would not happen, but here we are... smell and all.

When the sewer tunnel was being constructed the residents of Interlochen Drive were assured by Clare Muller and Kay Norwood that there would be completely adequate filters on the sewer vent at Roswell Road and there would be no smell. Based on this we all got behind the project and helped promote support for it. Now the street truly stinks and it seems nothing is being done. Please fix this !!!!

S
Seriously, this needs to be corrected! I endured over a year of blasting for the construction of the sewer tunnel and now this! The smell is horrific and our backyard is our haven.  We pay over $1,200/year for sewer and water service. Please fix it.

I have lived here in Buckhead for twenty years and this is simply unprecedented. The smell is simply overwhelming at times. How can this possibly be allowed to continue? I am certain that if one of our city leaders arrived home each evening to the smell of disgusting sewer-ness......over and over and over again, that this problem would be solved. Mayor Reed, where is the leadership?

I agree with all of the above comments.   On numerous occasions we have had to move inside because the smell was so horrid we couldn't enjoy our back yard.  Even having a fire in a fire pit doesn't mask the smell.  We supported the sewer project because we were assured that there would never be any odor from the sewer and now, with the stench occurring more often,  we all feel that we are getting no support from anyone in the city.  Please help.

I reaffirm Mac Ryland's comments above.  II used to live on Interlochen Drive and now live at Rosewood Plantation Condos on Roswell.  I can even smell the stench in my home at times.  Besides being a quality of life issue, this is getting to be a known aspect of living in our area, and will most assuredly affect our property values as well.  I have also emailed Ms. Adrean twice about this problem.  Please fix this!

Having several friends on Interlochen Drive, and because I live and shop nearby, this is a subject of great interest to me. The Chastain Square Publix is close to this stench pool, and Mirko Pasta Restaurant and Buttermilk Cafe are even closer to it.  Yesterday, (December 10) I turned from Lakemoore Drive onto Roswell Road heading to Mirko, and I thought something had gone terribly wrong INSIDE my car, even though the windows were raised.  This has to be a Georgia EPD issue if not a federal EPA issue.  In any case government attention to it should rise far above the City of Atlanta water department level.  If Mayor Franklin could resolve the Chattahoochee pollution crisis with the feds, surely Mayor Reed can nip this problem in the bud before it reaches state or federal fine level.

The smell is horrible and should not have to be endured.  Not only is it foul, it is embarrassing. I live on the corner of Roswell Rd and Interlochen and it is unbearable and totally unacceptable.  Our neighborhood deserves to have this issue addressed immediately.  Please move it to the top of the priority list.  I am personal friends with several of the local news reporters and plan to make a call to have this story covered if it is not addressed by the end of this week.

Totally agree and if someone is turning left onto highland there's a great chance you don't even make it through the light if you are more than 4 cars back.   This is supposed to be pedestrian friendly but having more cars lined up at the intersection, longer times to get through, and frustrated drivers will make things more dangerous for peds.

There should be a right turn lane here but the crosswalk should be well marked so that drivers stop BEFORE the crosswalk before turning right on red. A much worse intersection for pedestrians is Amsterdam and Highland headed east. Many a pedestrian has had a close call with drivers ignoring the crosswalk while turning right on red here.
The whole lane should have been narrowed, not just at the end.  The point is to stop cars from turning right on red without stopping.  I've had a few close calls with cars not stopping.

I think this "improvement" is another example of a knee-jerk reaction to a problem which does more harm than good. Atlanta's roads are being ruined one intersection at a time by these poorly-planned solutions.  Drivers can no longer turn right on red at this intersection in even moderate traffic, since there is no right turn lane any more.  Instead, there is a new curb which serves only to block traffic.

If the goal is to snarl traffic, why not make one lane of North Highland Ave a full-time bike lane, like was done recently to westbound 10th Street?  How about planting a giant Oak tree in the middle of the intersection of Piedmont and Monroe? Why not make the 4 left lanes of the Grady curve a drive-thru car wash?   

The lack of a comprehensive city-wide traffic plan is obvious.

The projects that you see happening at ponce between Piedmont and Spring are being funded by the Midtown Improvement District, not the city of Atlanta.  Unfortunately the block that you are referring to is well outside of our district so we are not able to spend funds there.  The City does have plans to improve Ponce--but I am not sure when these will take place.  I agree that Ponce is desperately in need of improvements along its length to Moreland.  The improvements in Midtown were done to calm traffic, improve the pedestrian environment, and two-way the street between Peachtree and Spring to improve traffic flow.  I hope this information was helpful.

I see no way what is being done at the top of thehill
will improve traffic flow especially making ponce
two-way between peachtree and spring.to begin, it is already difficult to get trucks into the fox controling traffic from one direction.  two directions would make it more difficult.  also bringing traffic up the hill from yet another direction would add to the
congestion at ponce and peachtree during rush hour and before and after performances

I stated my views and got retoric back so I'm chalking it up to money and power talks and 
By the people for people no longer means much .

That comment is a bit unfair--I gave  factual statements in response to your request for an explanation--not rhetoric.  I agree that Ponce needs more improvements further down the corridor--but the we are not allowed to spend MID funds outside of the MID district.  We hired transportation engineers to study the entire network of intersections in that area--14 in all--and devised a comprehensive plan to improve traffic flow in the area.  This project is the first part of that effort. We are also currently installing intelligent traffic signals that will be coordinated through a central monitoring location so they can be adjusted for special events (such as shows at the Fox), congestion, accidents, rush hour and so on.  The improvements to one intersection must be appreciated in the context of the whole.  I have hear that the Ponce streetscape to Moreland is moving forward so your concerns will be addressed.  I hope my response has answered some of your questions.

The City of Atlanta is in the process of prioritizing a list of sidewalk repairs for 2013.  This corridor was identified by Midtown Alliance staff as a high priority and a detailed survey was provided to the City for their consideration.  If this project does not make the list--then we will explore the possibility of repairing the sidewalk using Midtown Improvement District funds.  I will update this issue as more information is received.  Thank you again for reporting this issue.

Again, thank you for bringing this issue to our attention.  Sidewalk repairs within this section of 11th Street are actually part of a General Sidewalk Repairs capital project that is in the works. Our crews are working to place a bid for this construction and a new sidewalk constructed in this area by the 1st quarter of 2014.  We will continue to keep you updated with further details.  Thank you for keeping Midtown safe and clean.

Per City Code, repairs to sidewalks are the responsibility of the adjacent property owners. As it relates to the sidewalk on Eleventh Street between Piedmont and Juniper this is indeed the case.  However, Midtown Alliance has taken this issue down as part of our next phase of Sidewalk Repairs which will kick off later this year. Thank you for your time and patience.

The City either needs to enforce sidewalk responsibility on owners or take it upon themselves to provide repairs and improvements. The latter is the only sound approach in order to assure consistency and suitability. The response by the City and Modtown Alliance to this demonstrate a problem with government and urban planning. Explaining reasons for problems and shifting blame on area owners without insisting on enforcement is certain to continue to avoid solutions.

I opened this issue 541 days ago. Bill Kennedy Way is a major thoroughfare for cyclists, providing one of the safest I-20 crossings along the southeast corridor (only the Cherokee St. crossing in Grant Park provides a safer passage, but it doesn't provide for northbound trips or access to the beltline as well as BKW). All it would take would be some light demolition, rebuilding a short section of sidewalk and curb, and repaving a patch of the street. Hardly a TSPLOST-sized project scope.

This is clearly a problem endemic to your local (Atlanta) government, and your particular area isn't alone as far as being stuck in this conundrum. On the whole, SeeClickFix actually does work to bring about change such as street repairs in many communities (whether of the city or town size), but this online system by itself is only designed to be a reporting device; for things to actually happen after a complaint/request/suggestion is filed the relevant governing bodies have to have an active vested interest in local betterment, and unfortunately all too many appear to not give a hoot in this regard.
Well stated and I totally agree! I actually gave up years ago, yet I keep this active hoping that others will read it. Thank you!

You're quite welcome. By the way my friend, whatever you do, don't ever, ever give up. It is after all your seemingly inevitable total surrender (and concomitant subsequent silence), that "they" - the ultimate powers that be in Atlanta - are unquestionably after. They would like nothing more than for you to go away quietly while they go about "business as usual."
I promise to continue to fight this!!👊
Good for you; that's the spirit! :)

Thank you for reporting issue #150430.  Midtown Alliance is a non-profit organization working to improve the Midtown Community.   While basic infrastructure repair and maintenance remain the responsibility of the City of Atlanta, our full-time staff works to enhance these services in the district.  To this end, we address outstanding issues as quickly as we can and as our budget and authority allow.  For those issues that lie outside of our purview, we will advocate for resolution on your behalf.  As such, this issue has been passed along to the senior leadership at Georgia Tech and the City of Atlanta.  We will keep you updated with further details.  Thank you for keeping Midtown safe and clean.

Dear Sir/Madam,

Thank you for contacting the Citizen Help Center.

Service Request #1187197 has been submitted to the Roads and Drainage Department to patch/pave the area. Below please find information on the paving process.

 

The Roads and Drainage Division responds to requests for street resurfacing and/or paving. Each year a DeKalb County road rating engineering technician inspects approximately 2,115 miles of County roadway (consisting of more than 8,122 streets) using elements of the Georgia Department of Transportation's (DOT) pavement condition rating system to evaluate the structural condition of the roadways.

NOTE: The Asphalt Division of Roads and Drainage can supply road/street ratings and can be reached at 404.297.2563.

Twelve kinds of pavement distress are evaluated and each road will have a score between 0 and 60. Those streets with ratings of 30 or higher are eligible for submission to the Georgia DOT for possible resurfacing under their Local Assistance Resurfacing Program (LARP).

The schedule for street resurfacing is available on the County website (also see attached document)

http://www.co.dekalb.ga.us/publicwrks/roads_drainage/pdf/pavingList.pdf

We are unable to provide an estimate at this time on when the street will be resurfaced. We can send out a technician to inspect the conditions for patching and fill potholes.

 

 

 

Please feel free to call us at “311” within DeKalb County or 404 371-2000 outside of DeKalb County if we can further assist you.

 

 

Sincerely,

 

Cynthdella "Cindy" Thomas

311 Citizen Help Center

Dear Sir/Madam,

Thank you for contacting the Citizen Help Center.

Service Request #1181089 has been submitted to the Roads and Drainage Department as a Road Cave-in.

 

Roadway cave-ins are handled by the Roads and Drainage Department. If the hole is an open area, it is considered an emergency and will be addressed by the division within 24 hours. If the cave-in is not deemed an emergency, an inspection will occur within 30 business days.

If necessary the cave-in will be plated to secure the hole and will be added to a repair list based on the order received and the urgency of the cave-in.

 

 

 

 

 

Please feel free to call us at “311” within DeKalb County or 404 371-2000 outside of DeKalb County if we can further assist you.

 

 

Sincerely,

 

Cynthdella "Cindy" Thomas

311 Citizen Help Center

Thank you for contacting the Citizen Help Center. SR#1176121 has been submitted to the Roads and Drainage Department. Below, please find additional information on the criteria used by DeKalb for paving roads.

 

A:The Roads and Drainage Division responds to requests for street resurfacing and/or paving. Each year a DeKalb County road rating engineering technician inspects approximately 2,115 miles of County roadway (consisting of more than 8,122 streets) using elements of the Georgia Department of Transportation's (DOT) pavement condition rating system to evaluate the structural condition of the roadways.

Twelve kinds of pavement distress are evaluated and each road will have a score between 0 and 60. Those streets with ratings of 30 or higher are eligible for submission to the Georgia DOT for possible resurfacing under their Local Assistance Resurfacing Program (LARP).

The schedule for street resurfacing is available on the County website (also see attached document)

http://www.co.dekalb.ga.us/publicwrks/roads_drainage/pdf/pavingList.pdf

We are unable to provide an estimate at this time on when the street will be resurfaced. We can send out a technician to inspect the conditions for patching and fill potholes.

 

 

Sincerely,

 

Cynthdella "Cindy" Thomas

311 Citizen Help Center

I've lived in Boulevard Heights for 6 years and I don't drive over the tracks anymore due to damage from them. I've reported this problem countless times for 6 years and NOTHING has been done about it. Please see that this gets fixed.

It should also be noted that Atlanta's Fire Station #10 is located 1 mile north of this extremely bad crossing. Almost daily, the fire trucks, and other emergency vehicles, have to cross these tracks on emergency calls in which their speed has to be significantly reduced in order to cross the tracks. It is likely this crossing inhibits response time to emergencies. It is one of the worst RR crossings in all of Atlanta!
Kasim would like you to see these as a speed deterrent, not a defect.
It should be fixed.  And in the interim, there should be a sign put up telling people who don't know just how much they need to slow down!  This is a public disgrace.  No other word for it.
I avoid going over them unless it is absolutely necessary.  I have used them for directions to out of town friends.  Drive South on Boulevard, until you get air born, then turn left upon landing.

I would argue they are also a safety hazard, as people swerve into the oncoming lane to try and avoid driving over the severe pothole-likeness of the grate depression.  Also, it disrupts purpose of having two lanes for traffic flow, as most people that are aware of the issue drive in the right lane and then quickly change to the left lane if they wish to turn on the first road to left.  And, as has already been mentioned, it has to be doing damage to shocks, axles, etc.  It's ridiculous.

Sounds like a good opportunity for a gorilla art project - lots of bright colors all over the crossing bring attention to the rails from @#$%.  Might even get the attention of the AJC.  Set a date and time a few weeks in advance and we'll each bring a spare gallon of paint.  Cancel if any rain is forecast since the creek is down the hill.
BTW, I'm just kidding.  The best way to recycle your paint is at the city's annual Eco-Collection Day each spring at either Turner Stadium or Atlantic Station.
The RR crossing and the entire street should be fixed.  That section of Boulevard has been ignored long enough.  Fix the RR crossing and repave our street.

I have been  living in this area 9 years;  and yes, the Boulevard roadway between I-20 and the Federal Prison needs much attention. Our tax dollars should be doing something to improve the roadway. At a minimum, the Boulevard roadway should be on a well-publicized list for upgrading in the near future; if it is already on such a list, then we need to be made aware. 

 It is unacceptable that the road has been dismantled for sewer upgrades--I assume--but not re-paved in a decent  manner. It is embarrassing to have out of town visitors to have to travel down such an awful roadway year after year after year.

I've resorted to going off-road around them.  and i'm not the only one.  I drive a Sentra, and it says a lot that i'm wiling to drive that small car off-road to avoid the tracks.  The rubble on the right is smoother than the road.  Terrible.  F.
The only. Business that I know of that still use this spir is the concrete plant on Gleenwood LaFarge. If they would only help with this it is only right

This is a horrible portion of the road!!  I will never forget the first time I went over the tracks nearly 7 years ago - looked like a scene out of Dukes of Hazard (yes, I was airborne and my husband's head hit the top of the car!)  Every time I drive over it, I know a piece of my car dies a little.  We love having people over to our house, but hate that those that drive out have to be fore-warned of the treacherous tracks.  It should not be this difficult to fix; just do it right the first time!  We are (significant) tax paying individuals and would love to have a road that matches.

I did the same thing the very first time I drove over those tracks. I had no idea what happened due to the fact that is was 10 pm. It felt like the first hill on a roller coaster that ran over large pot holes on the way down. My then dog never wanted to go on car rides after that!
For years I have driven over the tracks on the outside lane (both directions) because  the inside lanes are in such poor condition. Past repairs have never lasted.
The rr tracks are awful on your vehicle. You have to almost come to a complete stop to pass them safely.

I have to chime in and agree in saying that the damage to my vehicle has been very costly.  Between the potholes and RR tracks, I have had to pay for re-alignments quite often.  At $100 bucks a pop, these add up.  Also, these issues wreak havoc on the struts and springs in the car!

Zach J

The railroad will need to work with the city to get permits.  Boulevard was closed for several days when repairs were made several years ago. More recently the street was closed for one day.

The cement company has other options for their sand delivery.  Their new cement facility is no longer dependent on the rails for sand delivery.  Now would be an excellent time to discontinue rail delivery of the sand to avoid rail repair costs.  If you contact the rail road owners or cement company, please let them know the entire community is anxious to move forward with the beltline during the current work shortage.

Unfortunately, this problem still isn't fixed.  CSX has done nothing to smooth out the railroad tracks and the work that the City of Atlanta performed didn't resolve the problem.  The center two lanes are still unusuable, and the outside lanes still require going less than 5 miles per hour.  This is a main throughfare for emergency vehicles, including the fire station just 1.5 miles north of these tracks.  The fire trucks also are required to slow to a crawl.  It is annoying that normal folks are required to drive over the grates and tracks at slow speeds.  It is UNACCEPTABLE that emergency/rescue vehicles are required to.
I've had to repair my car twice, due to this railroad track.
Agreed. This rail road crossing is dangerous and needs a permanent fix.
Why is the city so lazy about this?  They've been told that their fixes only last a few weeks, yet we get the same fix time and time again.  This has got to stop!!!
One of the grates here has now sunk about 6 inches.  It is an awful situation that needs immediate attention!
This railroad track has damaged many vehicles and is severe need of repair.
This problem as been here for so long. Seems like someone would PLEASE get it fixed........

If the issue weren't so serious, it would almost be laughable. Months ago, this section of Boulevard was brought to the attention of City of Atlanta and CSX officials; and CBS Atlanta News did an onsite story. Yet, the rail crossing and storm drain problems remain. It is a SAD statement that the concerted efforts, thus far, by SE Atlanta neighborhood leaders and residents, who've worked hard to bring attention to this rail crossing to have it PERMANANTLY fixed, have been futile. Somebody is "passing the buck" at the taxpayers expense and we should all be outraged! It's corporate and city government in-action at its worst!
Please help get a permanent fix!
Fix the tracks right!

Clairmont road is 4 lanes of heavy traffic due to the fact it bridges a large employment center including CDC, Emory, and the VA amongst many other offices and high density residential complexes in the area.

An auto is heading southbound and wants to turn left on Desmond (Desmond is a major cut through) to bypass the heavy traffic that gets clogged going southbound to North Decatur Rd.   There is a short left hand turn lane. (holds about 4 - 5 cars) The car sits at the left hand turn lane and there are 2 problems at this point:

1.   The amount of traffic lining up to turn left from Clairmont to Desmond can be significant and the left turn lane, again, is short.  This causes major traffic backup north up Clairmont Road as drivers on Clairmont Road heading south past this intersection only have one lane until they get past the intersection.  During rush hour the one lane backup can go all the way past the VA complex.
2.  The cars traveling northbound on Clairmont typically travel fast (an understatement), and are traveling fast around a sharp curve.  Its difficult to see them autos traveling around that intersection until the last few seconds.

To recap, an auto wants to turn left and often does not have the space which causes a traffic jam down Clairmont.  An auto wants to turn left and has poor visibility of oncoming northbound traffic.

Finally, another auto travels west on Desmond to the intersection of Clairmont.  The car wants to turn left to head south on Clairmont.  The auto has to cross 5 lanes (including the left turn lane on Clairmont) and navigate cars speeding around a sharp corner to their left (heading north), as well as heavy traffic heading south.

This intersection is a death trap and needs a traffic light before someone gets killed.  This is no joke.  Is it going to take someone having blood on their hands before it gets addressed?
ALWAYS make right turns, you'll end up ahead.

Agreed it's a dangerous turn where you feel like a sitting duck and the Desmond traffic pulls so far forward up the hill so they can see out to Claremont that it increases the radius of the left turn required to clear their car when you do get to make your left. But as a resident off Ava, off Desmond, id prefer if you just blocked the entrance to neighbors only. No more cutters! Its not even safe to walk our dogs or bike due to Waze sending all the cutters thru our cvommunity.

Thank you for contacting the call center, the request has been submitted over to the Roads and Drainage department and they will send an inspector out to the location to inspect the lot and give it a rating.

The Roads and Drainage Division responds to requests for street resurfacing and/or paving. Each year a DeKalb County road rating engineering technician inspects approximately 2,115 miles of County roadway (consisting of more than 8,122 streets) using elements of the Georgia Department of Transportation's (DOT) pavement condition rating system to evaluate the structural condition of the roadways.

Twelve kinds of pavement distress are evaluated and each road will have a score between 0 and 60. Those streets with ratings of 30 or higher are eligible for submission to the Georgia DOT for possible resurfacing under their Local Assistance Resurfacing Program (LARP).

As of the end of September, 2011, this issue still has not been fixed. Crosswalks in all other directions activate automatically, but the east/west signal on the south side of the intersection (directing bicycle and pedestrian traffic on the PATH) does not activate unless the button has been pushed. If bicycle or pedestrian traffic arrives after the east/west auto light has turned green, they must either proceed against the 'don't walk' signal, or wait an entire light cycle before receiving a walk signal. This is a heavily used commuter route and remains very dangerous and inconvenient.

I've come to the conclusion that the plastic bollards as implemented are effectively useless. I pass by these virtually every weekday, and there is always at least one knocked down. Every day I replace them, and the next day more are down again.

I believe this highlights the exact reason the bollards were put there in the first place -- to protect cyclists in the bike lane from cars turning right through the lane.

These should be replaced with permanent fixtures which stand a chance at actually preventing what they attempt to.
Picture of missing bollards, from this morning.

Agreed that this is a problem. Bollards should be constructed of a material that will both withstand and discourage contact, likely metal or concrete. How about a Jersey barrier? Undoubtedly, motorists have learned that driving over the existing plastic bollards has no adverse effects on their vehicle. Scarce city resources are being used to constantly replace these.

Also, I should note, these are very useful in forcing [most] motorists to slow down and take a wide turn, which helps immensely for preventing cyclists in the bike lane from getting squashed. Fix the issue, but don't discard the concept.

I find motorists travelling eastwards on Edgewood turning right onto Krog are liable to cut me off with the dreaded "right hook" when I'm cycling straight through intersection between the bollards and curb.   A more effective strategy would be the "stop line" for cars to be painted further back (~10 feet) and a separate "stop line" for bikes be painted forwards so as to be visible to drivers.   Instead of the flimsy plastic tubes we should consider a concrete barrier.

This car was parked in the bike lane on Monday. About a minute after taking the picture, the car pulled up next to me and started honking. The driver (whose wife apparently saw me taking the photo) began aggressively questioning me, taking pictures of me, and threatening legal action, as well as insinuating the possibility of other, supposedly more physical consequences. "You have to bike past here every single day. Could be very dangerous."

To me, he seemed very concerned about the possibility of his presence being associated with this particular location. Given his New Jersey plates, he probably wasn't too worried about receiving a cheap parking ticket from the APD that he won't ever have to pay. I won't speculate as to exactly what he was so concerned about, but I will note that every single car I've seen parked in this location has been different, and has had an out-of-state license plate. Which seems very strange to me.

The driver followed me to Inman Park station, at which point I entered the MARTA station to avoid further confrontation.

Mary, Adam & Ted,  one of my neighborhood watch groups sent out the attached information concerning traffic calming programs within neighborhoods. 
 
All the documents contain information on how to address speeders in your neighborhood & what the county requires to put in bumps.  I’m not sure how recent this information is, but here is a link to the “traffic calming” website which also includes information about sidewalks.  http://www.co.dekalb.ga.us/publicwrks/transportation/tr_faq.html#calming
 
The process in getting bumps must work because Creekdale Drive got them installed which made a huge difference after years of problems with speeders.
 
Mary & Adam, if you get push back from the Transportation Dept. on addressing the sidewalk, let me know.  We have a member of CALI who is in that department and we can use her influence to help.  Keep me posted….
 
Q.
How to I request a sidewalk to be installed on my street?
A.
To request a sidewalk, please call (770) 492-5204. A staff member of the Transportation Division will conduct a site visit of the area, develop a cost estimate and determine the priority of the request. Sidewalk requests that are near schools, transit and parks will be given priority over other requests. Priority will also be given to those roads that are classified as a collector, minor thoroughfare or major thoroughfare. Once a priority is established, funding sources will be sought for project construction.
 
Q.
How do I obtain traffic calming in my neighborhood?
A.
DeKalb County has developed a Traffic Calming Program to address the concerns of the citizens within DeKalb County. For a street to be eligible for the traffic calming program, it must be classified as local residential on the DeKalb County Thoroughfare Plan and have a posted speed limit of 30 mph or less. First, call (770) 492-5219 to receive an initial interest petition for your street. This petition is a screening to determine if at least 20% of the residents are interested in learning more about traffic calming. Once the initial interest petition passes, a traffic volume and speed study will be evaluated for all affected areas within the study area. If the study indicates that a speeding or cut though problem exists, then a stakeholders group will be formed and along with DeKalb County staff to develop a traffic calming plan for the area. To ensure citizen input, the development of the plan can take up to one year. The plan will then be presented to the Board of Commissioner’s (BOC) for approval. Once approved by the BOC, a petition for the installation and establishment of a special tax district will be circulated. A minimum of 65% approval from the property owners is required to install traffic calming devices.

On a Saturday ride with Va-Hi Velo we headed south on Highland from Aurora Coffee. We have ridden this stretch many times. I thought we were going straight towards downtown and was in the right lane. The group decided to go left at the light. Being very aware of the expansion joint. I approached carefully. I went to hop the joint and misjudged the distance, landing in the joint where it was about an inch deep. I fell catching my full wieght on my wrist. It was dislocated and had multiple breaks. Hopefully the image will spur some action on getting this fixed. I go for surgery, plate and screws tomorrow.

Over the years this expansion joint has injured many cyclist from pro racers in the Tour de Georgia to commuters indicating just how persistently dangerous this joint is.  We all know about it but it continues to injure us.   I remind my cycling friends about the expansion joint but we all come close to dropping our tires into it one day or another.  Riders will continue to be injured until it is fixed.

Rebecca - did your site visit with Public Works take place? If so, what became of the conversation? This side path remains extremely dangerous.

Yes, we had a site visit over a year ago I believe. Not much to report - the path had been built, the road realigned with less space and not enough room for bike lanes. My goals were to 1) help the city engineer understand why a sidepath would be less useful for city cycling than a bike lane to prevent this from happening in the future and b) to get ramps installed for access from side streets. 

Results were mixed. No ramps have been installed to my knowledge - I was told this was due to ADA, and the need to make the path safe for wheelchair users, which demonstrates why a bicycle lane was preferable in this location. The crossing at Piedmont remains very dangerous, as is the highway access ramp crossing - they did agree to install an additional sign warning of the ramp there. 

I would recommend contacting your city council member and copying the commissioner of public works on the email if you would like to weigh in. We gathered extensive feedback from cyclists but the reality is that once construction has started the advocates are too late. 

We started a neighborhood bicycle liaison program to try to stay better abreast of projects that affect conditions for cycling. Volunteers can "adopt" their neighborhoods by signing up here: http://www.atlantabike.org/node/1871

Hi Daniel,
This seems like a great issue to get some local cyclists to rally around. Have you tried contacting the Atlanta Bicycle Coalition (atlantabike.org)? If you get enough of your fellow cyclists involved, you could use SeeClickFix as an online petitioning tool. Acknowledged by ABC.

This is a systemic problem in Atlanta.  The reason is that when the Georgia DOT widens or rebuilds a road, they are required to strongly consider installing a bike lane, IF one is in the local bike plan.  So if they are widening 1/2 mile of road, that's how long the resulting bike lane will be.  

Our approach to this problem is to work with local government to take advantage of these existing spurts of bike lanes to create real connections. 

Briarcliff is quite narrow, which makes it hard to fit in bike lanes. I recommend you contact your county commissioner to tell them you want bike lanes on Briarcliff.  http://www.co.dekalb.ga.us/commission.htm
